DOC.HEAD: Source: CIA Tip Led to Mandela's Arrest in 1962
DOC.TEXT: A CIA tip to South African intelligence agents led to the 1962 arrest of anti-apartheid leader Nelson Mandela, who remained imprisoned until this year, according to a report published Sunday. The CIA had a ``deep cover'' agent in the Durban, South Africa, branch of Mandela's African National Congress, Cox News Service reported. Mandela, who had gone underground, was arrested on Aug. 5, 1962 while trying to leave Durban after secretly attending a dinner party there. Mark Mansfield, a CIA spokesman in Washington, said Sunday that agency policy ruled out any official comment on the allegations. Edward Ndlovo, a member of the ANC delegation in Geneva, Switzerland, dismissed the report, noting that CIA ties to the Mandela arrest have been rumored for years. ``That's an old, old story. I'm sure the press must have dug it up from newspaper cuttings from about five years ago,'' Ndlovo said. The report quoted an unidentified former U.S. official as saying that Paul Eckel, then a senior CIA operative, had told him within hours of Mandela's arrest that the capture was ``one of our greatest coups.'' The former official said Eckel told him: ``We have turned Mandela over to the South African security branch. We gave them every detail, what he would be wearing, the time of day, just where he would be. They have picked him up.'' Eckel, who retired about 10 years ago, died in 1986. Ndlovo said that when the allegations first surfaced, the ANC did not pay any attention to them. ``We just disregarded it. It's neither here nor there.'' The ANC had been a legal, peaceful organization for 48 years when it was outlawed in 1960. Mandela went into hiding and helped launch a sabotage campaign a year later. He was convicted of leaving South Africa illegally, then tried in 1964 along with other ANC leaders and convicted of sabotage and plotting to overthrow the government. He was freed in February. The report said the CIA's concern over Mandela arose from the belief that his activities against the South African government could harm U.S. interests. The two nations had signed a military agreement, and South Africa also was providing uranium to the United States. The late CIA Director William Casey in 1986 denied published reports that the United States has given South Africa intelligence on black nationalist groups.

DOC.HEAD: Kuwaitis Vote on Body Denounced by Opposition
DOC.TEXT: Kuwaitis on Sunday elected 50 members of a transitional parliament in voting boycotted by opposition leaders, who are challenging the government's claim that the new body will advance democracy. No results were available late Sunday, and it was unclear when results would be announced. Unofficial estimates after the polls closed at 8 p.m. put the turnout at about 55 percent in this small, oil-rich state on the Persian Gulf. Kuwait used to pride itself on having the only Western-style parliament among the conservative Arab countries of the Persian Gulf, but the government dissolved it in 1986 after strong parliamentary criticism of the government. The opposition boycotting the elections, led by about 30 deputies from the dissolved parliament, insist on the restoration of the original 50-member legislature instead of the 75-member transitional chamber, which includes 25 members appointed by Kuwait's emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmed al-Sabah Diplomats had said anything more than 40 percent at the polls should be considered a success for the government's plan to set up the interim 75-member National Council, given the boycott and the abstention of many Kuwaitis on summer vacation. The diplomats said it would be difficult to determine how many abstentions could be attributed to the opposition boycott. The emir decreed the new interim chamber to pave the way for the restoration of a fully elected parliament. However, opposition figures had argued the National Council would be unconstitutional and ineffective. The vote results were expected to produce a pro-government chamber that fosters cooperation between the executive and legislative branches of government. The all-male electorate, estimated at about 62,000, was choosing 50 deputies from among 348 candidates. Kuwait's population is 1.7 million. Only those over 21 who can trace their Kuwaiti citizenship back at least 30 years can vote. Women have not been enfranchised in this conservative Islamic society. Within four years, the interim chamber is charged with suggesting controls to prevent the kind of strong criticism of ministers that prompted the government to dissolve the parliament in 1976 and 1986. The 1986 suspension came at the height of the eight-year Iraq-Iran war, when Kuwait was almost dragged into the hostilities. But a U.N.-mediated cease-fire end the conflict in 1988. Then, with the democratic revolutions in Eastern Europe over the past year, activists in Kuwait began pressing for the restoration of parliament. The interim chamber was a compromise solution by the emir. Throughout its campaigns, the opposition has insisted that its allegiance to the emir remains firm. Before Sunday's election, the opposition held a series of meetings in defiance of laws banning public gatherings. Authorities arrested 15 opposition leaders, but they were later released. Later meetings were allowed to take place. The candidates are mostly new to politics. They overwhelmingly belong to pro-government tribes in outlying areas. But they include 20 onetime deputies who were members of parliaments elected since Kuwait's 1962 post-independence constitution. Only Arab reporters were allowed into Kuwait to cover the elections.

DOC.HEAD: Lightering Poses Potential for Disaster, Coast Guard Says
With AM-Tanker Blast, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The Coast Guard, noting a rise in the practice of transferring oil between ships in the Gulf of Mexico in recent years, said they have been bracing for a disaster. But the disaster officials feared was a collision, not the series of explosions that rocked the 853-foot supertanker Mega Borg on Saturday, killing two crewmen and leaving two others missing and presumed dead. As oil imports to the United States rise, the Coast Guard said the delicate art of ``lightering,'' or transferring oil from a larger ship to a smaller one, has been practiced more frequently in the gulf. Shippers say the transfers are necessary because the deep-water crude oil carriers are too large when fully loaded to navigate the relatively shallow Texas ship channels. As the Norwegian supertanker was transferring crude oil to the smaller tanker Framura on Saturday, an explosion set fire to the larger vessel. The blast occurred after the Mega Borg had unloaded 2.9 million of its 41.2 million gallons of oil, authorities said. The Coast Guard estimates that lightering operations off the Texas coast increased 200 percent between 1986 and 1988, the last year for which figures were available. From about 20 a month in 1986, transfers had jumped to an average of 77 a month by August 1988. More than a dozen oil transfer operations may be under way simultaneously off the coast of Galveston on some days, officials said. Although no major problems with lightering have been reported in the gulf, they said the disaster potential is increasing. As the number of transfer operations continues to rise, so does the possibility of a major oil spill along the Gulf Coast, Lt. Cmdr. Frank Whipple of the Coast Guard's Galveston marine safety office said earlier this year. ``It just takes one slip to cause a catastrophic accident,'' he said. Concern, however, has focused on the possibility of a collision between the two ships that must maneuver close to each other during the transfer. Officials worried a collision could pierce the hull of one of the tankers, causing a massive oil spill. Coast Guard officials, aware of the increasing risks, said they recently began closely watching the number and frequency of lightering operations off the Texas coast. Following the 10.9 million-gallon Exxon Valdez oil spill in Alaska last March, the Coast Guard ordered its marine safety offices throughout the nation to review disaster prevention and response plans. The agency requires a day's notice of arriving vessels and lightering schedules must be filed. Coast Guard inspectors said they visit the ships at owners' expense for safety inspections. Coast Guard officials met in January with lightering workers to discuss procedures, safety and the risk of a spill off the Texas coast. Industry officials estimate that 1.6 billion to 2.1 billion gallons of oil are lightered along the Louisiana and Texas coasts every year, with at least half that amount off Galveston.

DOC.HEAD: Tanker Blast Survivors Speak Escape Through Smoke and Darkness
With AM-Tanker Blast, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Crewmen from the Mega Borg, recounting their escape from the burning supertanker, told of feeling their way through darkened corridors amid acrid smoke and explosions. Ravishanker Navampally, an engineer on the 853-foot Norwegian ship, said he was just about to go to sleep early Saturday when he heard a loud noise and felt a strong vibration rock the crew quarters. The Calcutta, India, native said lights crashed down on him as he struggled from his cot and felt his way into the corridor. ``There was smoke. I didn't see fire,'' he said. Jose Emerson Bacinillo, a motorman from the Philippines who has spent 12 years at sea, said he woke to the cries of his friends. A power failure plunged the vessel into darkness, forcing crew members to feel their way along smoke-filled corridors to the deck. ``No light,'' said Bacinillo. ``I just walk in the alleyways,'' he said, demonstrating how he felt his way along the walls. ``I am scared also.'' The supertanker, which had 38 million gallons of light crude aboard, continued to burn out of control Sunday in the Gulf of Mexico after being hit by more explosions, authorities said. Two crewmen were killed Saturday, and two others were missing and presumed dead. John Angelo Estibeiro of India, a mechanic and pipe fitter on the vessel, said he is assigned to the same section of the ship where Coast Guard officials said the first blast occurred. ``I work during the day. If I worked at night, I may have been trapped in there,'' Estibeiro, 25, said while eating lunch Saturday at Brazosport Memorial Hospital in Lake Jackson. ``There is no escape at night. You don't know where to run,'' he said in broken English. Estebeiro said he went off duty at 8 p.m. Friday. Several hours later, he felt the ship shake. ``I was just on my way to go to sleep,'' said Estibeiro. ``My door was open. I heard a thump, and the lights fell on the floor because of the vibration.'' He rushed to the deck, along with most others on the tanker, and waited while a nearby crew boat came to the rescue. Two of the crewmen who escaped the fire and explosions were admitted to Brazosport Memorial Hospital; 15 others were treated for abrasions and smoke inhalation and released. The two who were admitted were in fair condition Sunday at the hospital about 15 miles north of Freeport, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Life Interesting For Family With 12 Members Named Frank
DOC.TEXT: Say hello to Frank J. Manibusan and his brother, Frank. And their brother, Frank. And their other brother, Frank. And his brother, Frank, and one other brother: Frank. Then, of course, there are their children: Frank, Frank, Frank, Frank, Frank and Frank. Frankly speaking, there are 12 Franks in all, at the moment _ 13 if you count the patriarch, 58-year-old Francisco. But hold on a minute. The sons and grandsons all have middle initials: J. J. J. J. J. J. J. J. J. J. J. and J. It isn't that their parents are sadistic pranksters who thought they'd have a good time at their son's expense, and that the joke was so funny the sons all played it on their sons. Not at all. They just didn't want to play favorites. ``As long as we keep having boys, they'll all be named Frank J.,'' laughed Barbara Manibusan, who's married to Frank John Manibusan, son No. 1. It didn't start out as a plan. It just ended up that way, explained Lolla Manibusan, who gave birth to all six boys and to two girls. Plagued by miscarriages _ seven in all _ Lolla Manibusan was told that babies weren't in her future. But after three miscarriages, she gave birth to a healthy boy. The couple, both from Guam, named him after the father, figuring he was a special _ and only _ child. But they were blessed again with another boy. ``We couldn't have him feeling bad,'' said Lolla Manibusan, reflecting on her frank decision. So he, too, was equipped with the ``F-word'' _ as the family likes to refer to it. They thought he'd be the last. But fate had other plans. ``When the third one showed up, we said, `There are two kids named after their dad _ what's going to happen?''' recalled dad Manibusan. Fair's fair, he finaly decided. ``I never dreamed it was going to be like Morton Salt _ when it rains it pours,'' Lolla Manibusan said at a Sunday family gathering at the parents' home. There is a distinction between the Frank J.'s. The J's are different. For the sons it's John, Joseph, Jesse, Jerry, Jady, and Joseph Haley. All Manibusans, every last Frank son (they range in age from 23 to 34), have settled down in Alameda. Life can get a little complicated for a bunch of guys with the same name. There was the time that Frank John went before a judge to clear a traffic ticket. No sooner did officials plug the name, Frank Manibusan, into the computer than it spewed out a ton of tickets. ``The judge wouldn't believe me that I had only four warrants,'' he joked. There can be a the light side, too. Can't do jury duty? Not to worry. Which Frank are the authorities going to chastise? And if one bro is out of cash, who cares? He need only tear out a check from his sibling's wallet. ``We don't leave no checks laying around,'' explained Frank Joe, No. 2 son, while his brothers and father nodded enthusiastically in agreement. While they get in trouble for the other's problems, they also get some rewards. Imagine Frank John's surprise when he got to work the day after his brother Frank Jady made the papers because the governor gave him an award for helping out in the Oct. 17 earthquake. ``They said, `Hey, Frank, I saw you in the newspaper. You're a hero.' I said that's my brother Frank Jady.'' Then his brother Frank Joseph made the papers for chasing a robbery suspect down the city streets waving a bat. When Frank Joe made the paper another time for chasing a second bad guy _ this one toting a gun _ Frank John's employer, Pacific Bell, wrote a story about his heroics. The anecdotes never stop, in the lives of the male Manabusans, to be perfectly frank.

DOC.HEAD: House Panel Wrapping Up Work on 1990 Farm Bill
DOC.TEXT: Members of the House Agriculture Committee plan to finish their work on the 1990 farm bill this week, while their counterparts in the Senate engage in open warfare over commodity prices. The last big issue in the House committee is the conservation section of the bill, which Chairman Kika de la Garza, D-Texas, said would be completed Tuesday. That's the day the Senate committee is to go public with its arguments over price supports, something the members have avoided in all their other work on the bill that sets agriculture policy for the next five years. Most problems with other sections have been resolved in closed meetings between the Democratic and Republican staffs. When the staffs couldn't resolve the commodity price support problems, committee Chairman Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., appointed a ``working group'' of himself, Sens. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb., David Pryor, D-Ark., Richard Lugar, R-Ind., Bob Dole, R-Kan., and Thad Cochran, R-Miss. When the group couldn't resolve the problems, the chairman decided to go to open session and settle the matter through voting. ``I think we will end up getting a bill reported out,'' Kerrey said last Friday. ``It won't be what Lugar wants. It won't be exactly what I want.'' Kerrey took the lead among the Democrats in the committee who proposed increasing price supports 1 percent in 1991 and allowing other increases in the four subsequent years based on inflation rates. Lugar's proposal represented the Bush administration's position that price supports should be frozen at 1990 levels. Kerrey said his proposal would cost $13 billion in 1991. ``We only got $10.6 billion from the Budget Committee,'' he said. He said, however, that Leahy had told him he wouldn't take a bill to the full committee unless it had support of all the Democrats on the panel, was within the budget and could bring in some of the Republicans. ``I think we have every disagreement settled except for the loan rates,'' said Kerrey. Lugar told reporters early last week that he would not accept anything other than a freeze in target prices and loan rates. He said if Democrats wanted to make an issue of it, they would find themselves in a floor battle that could lead to a one-year extension of current law. ``The administration wants a one-year extension,'' said Kerrey. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter has said repeatedly that an extension would be acceptable because international trade talks known as GATT, to be completed in December, could create a need for a change in support policies anyway. In a session with reporters last Friday, Rep. Charles Stenholm, D-Texas, a subcommittee chairman on the House Agriculture Committee, pointed out the some problems with an extension. ``Why would you want to go through the same debate twice within a 12-month period,'' he said. ``There's no such thing as a simple one-year extension when you are dealing with the quirks in the law and the budget summit.'' Congress and the White House have been talking for weeks about ways to reduce the federal deficit in what is being referred to as a budget summit. `'You have to have certainty in the agriculture program,'' said Stenholm. ``In a one-year extension, there's no certainty.''

DOC.HEAD: 80 Graves Desecrated in American Jewish Cemetery
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to ADD date of oldest graves. Pickup 5th graf pvs, `Some 80...'
DOC.TEXT: Vandals desecrated 80 tombstones in the American section of the more than 2,500-year-old cemetery on the biblical Mount of Olives, police said Sunday. Police took the cemetery's Arab guard in for questioning after the desecration was discovered early Sunday. A police spokesman said there were no suspects. Israel television said, however, that police suspected Palestinian nationalists were behind the attack. Jewish tradition holds that the Mount of Olives is where the Messiah will appear and the Prophet Ezekiel will blow the trumpet of resurrection. Many prominent rabbis are buried in the cemetery, the largest and oldest Jewish graveyard in the world. Rock-hewn tombs at the foot of the mountain date back to the time of King Solomon's temple, which was destroyed by the Babylonians in 586 B.C. Some 80 tombstones or raised limestone graves were smashed, crushed or toppled in two sections of the graveyard, located on the side of the biblical mount in annexed east Jerusalem overlooking the walls of the Old City. Flowers and memorial candles were strewn over the site, and the names of many of the deceased could not be read because of the damage. ``The must have come here with 12-pound hammers. I don't know how they didn't hear this,'' Yonatan Shamai said, pointing to Arab homes some 50 yards away. ``I heard the report on the radio. It sent chills down my spine. I had to come and see for myself,'' said Shamai, a 43-year-old diamond worker. He said his father is buried in the graveyard, but his tomb was not among the damaged. Jerusalem Mayor Teddy Kollek denounced the desecration and warned that it may further disrupt Jewish-Arab relations in the city, already severely harmed by the 30-month Palestinian uprising. ``An attack on such a sensitive site is destructive for efforts to encourage understanding and tranquility that we are trying to establish between Jews and Arabs in the city,'' Kollek said in a statement. The incident follows a wave of similar desecrations, including one in southern France and one in the northern Israeli port of Haifa. After the desecration of 34 graves in the French town of Carpentras last month, two members of a Jewish Messianic cult desecrated more than 300 Jewish graves in Haifa with spray-painted slogans calling on Arabs to kill Jews. The two confessed and said they had hoped that Arabs would be blamed for the destruction. One was sentenced to three years in prison, and the other was found psychologically unfit to stand trial. Although suspects were questioned in the French case, no one was charged.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0697 to fix computer garble in slugline
Mass Rallies Broken up in Kirghizia; Death Toll Now 115
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE death toll, TV footage; No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Police broke up attempts to organize nationalistic rallies Sunday in the Central Asian republic of Kirghizia after a week of ethnic clashes that have left 115 people dead, officials said. The border city of Osh in western Kirghizia, where fighting between ethnic Kirghiz and Uzbeks broke out last weekend, was reported calm Sunday. At issue was the allocation of land for housing in the densely populated, poor region. The ethnic violence was only the latest to confront Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. Nationalities in several republics have taken advantage of Gorbachev's reforms to vent frustrations over political and economic woes. In Osh, armored personnel carriers sat at each intersection and Interior Ministry troops patrolled the streets, said Rauf Duseyev, duty officer at the Osh Communist Party offices. But unrest continued Saturday in nearby regions, especially in Uzgen, which is predominantly Uzbek, Soviet TV reported Sunday night. In Frunze, the capital of Kirghizia and 195 miles north of Osh, students trying to organize rallies in the capital's main square were turned back by Interior Ministry troops and police, said Ivan Pavlov, a party official. Rallies in Frunze last week turned into demonstrations against the republic's leaders. There were also calls for residents to join the battle against the Uzbek population in Osh. Early Sunday, officials from the Communist Party and the government visited student and worker dormitories to talk them out of holding the rallies, Pavlov said from Frunze. Armored personnel carriers rolled along the main streets of Frunze in districts where trouble had broken out earlier, and all was quiet, he said. Overnight in Frunze, 11 students threw stones at a police patrol from a dormitory window and were beaten by the truncheon-wielding officers, Pavlov said. There were no serious injuries, and no one was detained in the incident, he said. Since the Kirghiz-Uzbek unrest began on June 2, 115 people have died, 468 have been wounded, the Soviet television newscast ``Vremya'' reported Sunday night. The Soviet army newspaper Red Star said about 500 houses have been burned down. It also said 512 people were arrested, including 47 for curfew violations and 11 for possession of firearms. Rioting flared in Osh, a 3,000-year-old city of 210,000 people, when Uzbeks, one-third of the population, discovered that Kirghiz were being given parcels of land for housing. Housing is critically short in the republic. The fighting between the Sunni Moslem groups spread to districts around Osh, and thousands of troops were sent in to reinforce local police. Soviet troops sealed off the border to prevent thousands of Uzbeks from crossing into Kirghizia to join the battle, and curfews were imposed in the region, including Osh, Frunze and border areas inside Uzbekistan. Soviet and local officials have appealed repeatedly for the residents of both republics to remain calm. In the district of Nauket, near Osh, elders of the Uzbek and Kirghiz communities met over the weekend to ask youths to cool their tempers, Komsomolskaya Pravda reported. Monday was declared a day of mourning in Osh. Although public transportation resumed in Osh over the weekend, shooting was reported in the suburbs, Komsomoloskaya Pravda reported. Footage of burned-out shells of homes and charred autos was shown on the newscast. Yet, it also featured Kirghiz and Uzbek residents of Osh discussing the situation together, in an apparent effort to portray instigators of the violence as extremists. In the Kirghiz town of Uzgen, 35 miles outside Osh, shooting and arson attacks continued Saturday, the newspaper said. Some of the worst bloodshed has occurred in the Uzgen district, where two-thirds of the deaths were reported. Red Star said an Interior Ministry officer was shot to death at a local post in the Osh region. It said it believed bands of citizens who had obtained police uniforms and guns were roaming the region and firing at civilian targets to provoke the population.

DOC.HEAD: Tradition Remains Strong Despite Cruising Limits
DOC.TEXT: Cruising thrived for one special night in the town that styles itself the Cruising Capital and inspired the film ``American Graffiti.'' ``It's pure hysteria,'' Ray Brooks, 48, said as he pulled his 1928 Ford truck onto McHenry Avenue for its first pass of the night Saturday in this central California city's annual Grafitti Night. No matter that it took as long as three hours to negotiate the five-mile McHenry cruising strip among some 25,000 vintage and late model cars. On Graffiti Night, speed takes a back seat to showing off cars and meeting dates. ``I think what's special about the night is all the people,'' said Tom Greco, 45. Passers-by flocked like moths to the flashing purple and blue neon spark-plug wires on Greco's 1929 Ford. Not to be deprived of cruising's rites just because they were on foot, a pair of pedestrians answered the wail of a tractor-trailer horn with blares from fog horns they carried. People came from miles around to join the revelry. An estimated 70,000 to 80,000 pedestrians made the sidewalks as prone to gridlock as the avenue. Still, the crowds parted easily for Larry Wooldridge, who had a 14-foot python around his neck. More than 200 police officers patrolled in cars and on foot. Police Lt. Dennis Puthuff said 85 people were arrested, mostly for drinking in public, though one person was held for felony assault with a deadly weapon. Following the plot of the 1973 film ``American Graffiti,'' directed by Modesto native George Lucas, high school seniors 15 years ago established Graffiti Night on the first Saturday after graduation. Many regard the film as a documentary of sorts on the cruising tradition, and say it established this city of 130,000 as the Cruising Capital. As longtime cruiser Bill Miller of Phoenix puts it, ``Cruisers revere Modesto.'' Modesto's primacy as the cruising mecca was threatened by the approval in March of two ordinances to limit the gasoline-guzzling pastime. The rules impose fines for loitering on foot and for passing (on wheels) checkpoints more than twice. Supporters said the cruising tradition popularized in the 1950s is no longer good natured when influenced by 1990s-style vandalism, drugs and gangs. Graffiti Night, however, is the one time each year the fines don't apply, and revelers took full advantage. ``We are the original Graffiti people,'' said Pam Vieira, Turlock High School class of 1962. Vieira and her companions spent much of the evening watching the parade from the back of their 1954 Chevy pickup truck after it overheated in the crawling traffic. They weren't alone. Parking lots became impromptu vintage automobile shows while late model cars dominated the strip, diluting what many identify as the true cruising experience. ``That's not what cruising's about. It's about talking to the guy in the car next to you or the girl in the car next to you. If the stereo's blaring, how are you going to get to know them and marry them,'' said Charlotte Mallory, 44, with her husband in a 1960 Morris Minor. They met while cruising in San Leandro, and reared two teen-age daughters ``in the back seat of a car cruising,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Ruling Party Certain to Win As Opposition Boycotts Elections
DOC.TEXT: The ruling Constitutional Democratic Rally Party seemed certain to win Sunday's balloting for 246 municipal councils in elections boycotted by opposition parties. The ruling party's candidates were contested by independent candidates in only 19 municipalities, leaving abstention as the only way for most of the 1.7 million voters to express discontent with President Zine el Abidine Ben Ali's rule. It was unclear if a significant number of voters boycotted the polls, which closed at 6 p.m. Observers said voting for the 3,774 seats took place in an atmosphere of calm. Officials said preliminary figures on voter turnout would probably not be available until Monday. Official results might take longer. Right-wing and left-wing parties announced a boycott of the elections while Islamic Fundamentalists were banned from the balloting. In the last legislative elections, held in 1988, the ruling party won every seat in the national assembly. Opposition parties later accused the party of abusing its control of state funds, transport and mass media. The Constitutional Democratic Party has held power since French colonial rule ended decades ago. Municipal and regional elections will be held Tuesday in neighboring Algeria, the first time that nation's ruling National Salvation Front has faced a challenge from opposition parties. The officially recognized fundamentalist Islamic Salvation Front is expected to pose the strongest challenge to the Front, which has ruled Algeria since independence from France in 1962.

DOC.HEAD: Sister Recalls Slain Woman's Liaison With FBI Agent Who Reportedly Killed Her
DOC.TEXT: A woman searching for her pregnant sister, a onetime FBI informant, learned the sister had been strangled after a lovers' quarrel with a married FBI agent, the woman says. Susan Daniels Smith, 28, dropped out of sight last June after threatening to expose the two-year affair and her pregnancy to the agent's wife, said sister Shelby Ward. Her body was found last week. ``She wanted him to leave his wife. She was threatening to tell his wife about the baby and he was scared to death,'' Mrs. Ward said. The FBI agent admitted killing the woman during an argument and was expected to plead guilty to manslaughter this week, she said. No charges have been filed, but law enforcement authorities speaking on the condition they not be identified confirmed Mrs. Ward's story. Greg Jones, an FBI spokesman in Washington, refused to comment on the case. When asked whether he knew of any cases where an FBI agent was charged in a homicide, he said: ``I don't believe there ever has been.'' The agent, identified by Mrs. Ward and other sources as Mark Putnam, ``confessed to killing my sister and where he put the body,'' Mrs. Ward said. She said she and her brother, Billy Joe Daniels, were briefed on the case last week. Human skeletal remains found at the dumping sight are those of a white adult female, officials said. Mrs. Ward said authorities told her the remains are her sister's. Outraged at the plea agreement, Mrs. Ward defied prosecutors' wishes and discussed the case with The Associated Press. ``It's cold-blooded murder to me,'' she said. She threatened to file a lawsuit against the agent, and possibly the FBI, seeking damages to help support Ms. Smith's children, ages 8 and 4. The victim was an eighth-grade dropout who married at age 15 and was later divorced, her sister said. She was an FBI informant who testified in a bank robbery case and worked on a vehicle-theft case, Mrs. Ward said. Ms. Smith and the agent met during her work as an informant, her sister said. The victim told of the affair, naming Putnam and saying he was a married FBI agent. She was last seen June 8, 1989, after traveling to Pikeville to meet the agent at a motel three days before, Mrs. Ward said. ``She was possessed by him ... madly in love with him,'' the sister said. ``We tried to get her to date other people and she didn't even want to talk about it.'' Authorities did not say whether the fetus' death would result in added charges. ``She was even going to name it after him, if it was a boy,'' Mrs. Ward said. The agent told authorities he strangled Ms. Smith during an argument on their way back to Freeburn, Mrs. Ward said. Her nude body was dumped the next day off the side of a rural road in Harmond Branch, about five miles north of Pikeville, she said. Mrs. Ward reported her sister missing on June 12, after the agent called ``in a panic'' and said Ms. Smith had gone to Chicago. Mrs. Ward said she suspected foul play when her sister's purse, clothes and makeup were found at the motel. ``That was a new outfit. She would have put it on if she was going to go somewhere,'' Mrs. Ward said. The agent allegedly said he stripped the body because the victim was wearing his clothes when she died. Putnam reportedly was transferred from Pikeville to Miami in May 1989. The killing took place during a trip back to Kentucky for court proceedings in a case he worked on. Attempts to reach Putnam for comment were unsuccessful. Directory assistance in Miami had no listing for him and FBI officials there referred all calls to Washington headquarters. Putnam has been on administrative leave for at least a month, said sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. He faces a possible 16-year prison term. Mrs. Ward said she and her brother were told of the agent's confession and the plea arrangement by Pike County prosecutor John Paul Runyon, state police Capt. Gary Rose and Kentucky FBI supervisor Terry O'Connor. ``The family's been wondering all this time,'' Mrs. Ward said. ``And all this time, (she has been) laying over there, nothing but her skeleton.''

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Injured Baby, Link Sought to Animal Rights Groups
With AM-Animal Rights, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A bomb placed on an animal researcher's car exploded Sunday in this western English city and seriously injured a nearby 13-month-old boy, police said. No one immediately claimed responsibility, but authorities said they were investigating any connection with a bomb attack Wednesday on the car of a veterinarian near Salisbury. After the first attack, a telephone caller claimed responsibility for an animal rights' group. The baby injured Sunday was identified as John Cupper. He suffered burns, shrapnel wounds and a partially severed finger, police said. The boy's father, James Cupper, and the driver of the car, Patrick Headley, escaped injury. Headley, a psychologist at Bristol University, has been involved in research projects on sheep, according to Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency. Deputy Chief Constable John Harland of Avon and Somerset Police said detectives were investigating links with Wednesday's bomb attack on the veterinarian's car. In last week's incident, a bomb set fire to a car driven by Margaret Baskerville, a veterinarian employed by the Ministry of Defense's Chemical Defense Establishment at Porton Down, near Salisbury in southern England. That facility uses mice and guinea pigs in experiments on countermeasures for chemical and biological warfare agents, the Ministry of Defense said. Mrs. Baskerville escaped injury. Chief Inspector Bryan Saunders, a spokesman for Avon and Somerset Police, said police were warning all people involved in animal research to ``take every precaution, in particular to check their vehicles for suspect devices.'' Sunday's attack came the same day up to 50,000 animal rights activists rallied in Washington to promote the humane treatment of animals in the wild, on farms and in research laboratories. Many marchers advocated an end to using animals in medical research.

DOC.HEAD: Cold Front Brings Scattered Showers to the West
DOC.TEXT: A cold front brought scattered showers from the northern Rockies to Southern California, and rain also fell in the southern Applachians and western New England. Showers and a few thunderstorms developed from western Arkansas to southeastern Nebraska and scattered thunderstorms formed along the Gulf Coast. Rain fell in New Mexico, Colorado, Nevada, Idaho and Washington state. San Diego had its second straight day of record rain, with .4 inch falling, easily surpassing the total of .14 on the same date in 1957. Skies were sunny from the southern High Plains to Georgia and across the upper Mississippi Valley and the upper Great Lakes region. Strong northwesterly winds blew over the upper Great Lakes region and the middle Atlantic Coast. The low for the Lower 48 states was 44 degrees in Olympia, Wash.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuits Claim Insurer Bypassed Laws On `Working Aged'
DOC.TEXT: The nation's health-care system for the elderly has been bilked of huge sums _ perhaps billions of dollars _ by private insurance companies that refuse to pay their share, according to a series of legal actions. In lawsuits by federal officials and a Miami law firm, a Chattanooga, Tenn.-based insurer, Provident Life and Accident Insurance Co., is accused of circumventing an 8-year-old revision in Medicare policy designed to make insurers pay 80 percent of medical costs for working people 65 and older. Previously, the so-called ``working aged'' had 80 percent of their medical bills paid by Medicare. The lawsuits were filed quietly 14 months ago, but are just now moving into the courtroom. The attorneys from the Miami law firm said their lawsuit accuses four other private insurers of such tactics, while the U.S. Justice Department has become involved only in the Provident action. The lawsuits allege that the insurance company knowingly paid only 20 percent of the bill and counted on Medicare to cover the rest. The 1982 revisions were made to ease financial pressure on the $97 billion-a-year program. ``This is fraud, pure and simple,'' said Miami attorney Luis Bustamante, who says he uncovered the Medicare losses while representing a client in 1983. ``It's a monster,'' Bustamante said in an interview last week. The Senate Governmental Affairs Committee's permanent subcommittee on investigations is scheduled to begin hearings next month on the allegations. But there is discord among the accusers. Bustamante and colleagues in the Stinson, Lyons, Gerlin & Bustamante law firm of Miami claim the Justice Department merely copied their action against Provident after reviewing piles of documents and depositions the Miami law firm gathered. Justice Department officials did not answer numerous calls to their Washington office last week seeking comment. ``The whole Medicare system is based on trust. It's so open for abuse,'' said Bustamante. Bustamante said he first learned of the Medicare problem while representing Miami trucking executive Armlon Leonard. Leonard, 67, was severely injured in a 1983 car crash and spent 15 months, including a year in intensive care, at Miami's Jackson Memorial Hospital before he died. His medical bill: $800,000. While reviewing Leonard's medical bills, Bustamante said, he learned that Provident Life and Accident Ins. Co. did not uphold its $1 million policy, claiming it was reduced to $50,000 of coverage after Leonard turned 65 and became eligible for federal coverage. Bustamante says his probe indicated that some companies never started picking up the increased tab for the ``working aged'' required under the amended law. The companies allegedly would allow Medicare to pick up 80 percent, then send only 20 percent, instead of sending 80 percent themselves and allowing Medicare to get a refund. Bustamante filed a False Claims Act lawsuit in Miami in March 1989, alleging Provident was failing to pay its required 80 pecent of Leonard's bill. The 127-year-old federal False Claims Act, broadened in recent years, allows private citizens to file fraud allegations against the government or act as whistle blowers when federal programs are abused. The Justice Department reviewed Bustamante's claim and the accompanying mass of documents, and eventually filed its own action. ``Everything was there and more,'' said Leon Weinstein, a former special agent for the office of inspector general of the Department of Health and Human Services assigned to the Bustamante case. Both lawsuits have been transferred to Chattanooga, Tenn., Provident's home base, but a judge stayed Bustamante's suit in favor of the federal action. Bustamante said his investigation has turned up stacks of evidence of Medicare fraud, including depositions and internal documents at Provident. Provident says it's not going to talk about the legal action, for now. ``The company's position is that we're not discussing this while it's in litigation,'' said Provident spokeswoman Jennie Storey. But the company has denied wrongdoing in court documents and is vigorously fighting the action. On Monday, Provident is scheduled to appear at a hearing in Chattanooga on its request to block the author of a memo from testifying in court in the Justice Department case. Medicare officials have said that underpayments by private companies could run into the billions of dollars. Bustamante's lawsuit also names Prudential Insurance Co. of America, based in Newark, N.J.; Jefferson-Pilot Life Insurance Co. of Greensboro, N.C.; Atlanta-based Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Georgia; and Pan American Assurance Co. of New Orleans.

DOC.HEAD: Conservatives Organize for Russian Party Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Conservative Communists critical of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's reforms organized Sunday to fight for control of a new party for the largest Soviet republic, a spokesman said. If they succeed, they will be heading on a collision course with the Russian republic's government, whose new president is radical reformer Boris N. Yeltsin. The unofficial North-West news service of Leningrad reported that radical reformers picketed the entrance to the House of Political Education in that city, where Sunday's meeting took place. The session of almost 600 party members was called to prepare for a conference of all Russian Communists scheduled for Tuesday in Moscow. They picked a slate of candidates for that meeting and drafted a proposed platform criticizing national policies. Organizers say there are more than 1.5 million national party members in the Soviet Union's largest republic. Most republics also have their own parties within the national organization. As the giant Russian republic seeks its place in a rapidly changing union, it is founding its own party too. Russians say they need the party because their interests have long been secondary to national concerns and they have lost their identity. However, as in most other republics, the Russians are expected to form a party under the umbrella of the Soviet Communist Party. In the secession-minded Baltics, the Communist parties have broken with the Kremlin. If the conservatives gain control of the new Russian party, they would exercise broad power over policies and party apparatus in the republic that includes 52 percent of the Soviet population and three-quarters of its land. Vladimir Komarov, a spokesman for the conservatives, said their proposed platform is consistent with resolutions approved in April at an initial gathering in Leningrad. Those resolutions accused Gorbachev's economic advisers of orienting reforms toward a ``small group of people.'' ``The path they propose leads to a full break with socialism,'' the document said. The Leningrad group proposes to push the Soviet Union out of its economic crisis in party by relying on scientific and technological advancements, Komarov said. The gathering also agreed on a list of more than 100 candidates it is promoting for the Central Committee of the new Russian Communist Party. Komarov said about 80 percent of them are workers or peasants. It is unclear how much support the Leningrad group has among Russian Communists, but their meeting represented a minority of rank-and-file party members.

DOC.HEAD: Another Rise in Gas Prices, Survey Says
DOC.TEXT: Gasoline prices took another small hike upward nationwide, according to a survey of service stations released Sunday. The average price for a gallon of gas, including all taxes, was 117.96 cents as of Friday, according to the Lundberg Survey of nearly 13,000 stations nationwide. The average price marked a rise of 1.91 cents from the last survey May 18. The May 18 price was a hike of 2.4 cents over the previous check. The survey had a holiday break giving a three-week lag between the last check and the one released Sunday. It usually is conducted each two weeks. Gas prices generally rise during the summer as drivers hit the road for vacations, increasing demand. The average price at self-serve pumps: regular unleaded, 106.50 cents per gallon; premium unleaded 123.65; and regular leaded 106.18. For full-service pumps: regular unleaded 132.40 cents per gallon; premium unleaded, 146.01; and regular leaded, 128.60.

DOC.HEAD: Susan Saint James Has Baby Boy in Connecticut
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CHANGES `St.' to `Saint' throughout to conform with actress's preference.
DOC.TEXT: Television actress Susan Saint James gave birth to a baby boy Sunday, a spokesman at Charlotte Hungerford Hospital said. Saint James, who lives in Litchfield, had an 8-pound, 14-ounce boy at about 10:30 a.m., said spokesman hospital Richard Bisi. Both mother and child were doing fine, he said. Saint James, 43, has had a long career as a television actress. Most recently, she co-starred with Jane Curtin on CBS' situation comedy, ``Kate and Allie.'' She starred in ``McMillan and Wife'' with Rock Hudson from 1971-1977. Saint James won a best supporting actress Emmy playing an offbeat secretary in ``The Name of the Game,'' which ran from 1968-71. She also appeared in such movies as ``Carbon Copy'' and the vampire spoof ``Love at First Bite.'' This is Saint James' third child with her husband, former Saturday Night Live producer Dick Ebersol. She has two children from a previous marriage. The couple plans to name the baby Edward Bright Ebersol, a hospital spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: White Teens Face Sentencing in Racial Slaying
DOC.TEXT: Two white teen-agers convicted in the mob slaying of a black youth face sentencing Monday as community leaders try to prevent any resumption of the racial violence that erupted at the end of their trial. In a killing that fueled already simmering racial tensions, 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins was shot in August after he and three black friends were chased by a mob in Bensonhurst, a predominantly white Brooklyn neighborhood. Joseph Fama, 19, was convicted May 17 of second-degree murder and other crimes, including riot, unlawful imprisonment and illegal weapons possession. He faces a maximum of 32 and two-thirds years to life in prison. A second jury acquitted Keith Mondello, also 19, of murder and manslaughter charges on May 18, but found him guilty on the lesser charges of riot, unlawful imprisonment and discrimination. Prosecutors want Justice Thaddeus Owens to give Mondello consecutive sentences, which could keep him in prison from 5 1-3 years to 16 years. If his sentences run concurrently, Mondello, the alleged ringleader of the attack, could serve as little as 1 1-3 years to four years in prison. After the conviction of Fama, who some witnesses said fired the fatal shot, the city remained calm. But when Mondello's acquittal on the murder charge came, mayhem erupted in the courtroom and in the streets. Crowds of blacks assembled across Brooklyn, hurling rocks and bottles and blocking traffic. Several white news reporters were injured, none seriously. The Rev. Al Sharpton, a flamboyant civil-rights activist described by some as a headline-hungry rabble rouser, has adopted the role of peacemaker. ``We don't have to like each other, but we have to live with each other,'' Sharpton said recently from the steps of City Hall. To back up his appeal for racial calm, Sharpton canceled the weekend protest marches he has staged in Bensonhurst. Leaders of the largely Italian-American neighborhood promised to work with the black community to help heal racial conflicts. ``Bensonhurst will show the world that people who have been represented as enemies can come together and live the life of the lamb, not the lion,'' said state Assemblyman Frank J. Barbaro. After the sentencing on Monday, Owens is scheduled to conduct a final pretrial hearing and begin jury selection in the trial of John Vento, 21, another accused member of the gang. Initially, Vento was the cornerstone of the prosecution's case. He admitted joining the mob and agreed to testify against other participants in exchange for immunity from prosecution. But Vento backed out of the deal and fled the city shortly after Christmas. He surrendered to the FBI in Dayton, Ohio, in March. A few days later, he was charged with murder and other crimes in the attack.

DOC.HEAD: Racketeering Trial For New Orleans District Attorney To Begin
DOC.TEXT: District Attorney Harry Connick goes on trial Monday on federal charges he helped an arrested bookie continue his gambling operation, an accusation Connick calls ``pure D baloney.'' In addition to Connick, actor Paul Burke, who starred in television's ``The Naked City;'' former federal prosecutor Patrick Fanning; businessman Wilson Abraham; convicted bookmaker Walton Aucoin and Aucoin's alleged employees, Steve Bertolino and William Condon, are on trial in U.S. District Court. If convicted of racketeering and aiding an illegal gambling operation, Connick could be sentenced to 25 years in prison and fined $250,000. ``I did nothing wrong,'' Connick said last December when he was indicted. ``The allegations are pure D baloney.'' Prosecutors from the Justice Department in Washington are handling the case, but Connick blamed New Orleans' native U.S. attorney, John Volz, for the indictment. Volz and Connick have had well publicized feuds over the years and Connick said the charges against him were the result of a Volz vendetta. ``He knows it's a damn lie and everyone else who knows me knows it's a damn lie,'' Connick said after his arraignment last year. He has since been mum on the subject, saying he'd prefer to present his case at trial. Volz began the federal investigation of Connick. He said he turned the case over to Washington prosecutors to avoid any appearance of bias or conflict of interests involving Connick or Fanning. Fanning once was an assistant to Volz. In the indictment, Aucoin, Bertolino and Condon were accused of owning and conducting a New Orleans-based illegal interstate gambling operation that netted up to $2,000 a day. Fanning, Abraham and Burke were charged with aiding the operation by helping Connick cook up an excuse for returning the seized records Aucoin needed to keep it going. Aucoin was arrested in December 1988. Connick has said he acted in accordance with state criminal procedures, which allow defendants to see evidence against them so their attorneys can prepare a defense. Connick, district attorney in New Orleans since 1973, is up for re-election this fall. The father of Grammy-winning jazz musician Harry Connick Jr., he made news nationally last year when he joined state Attorney General William Guste in asking a federal court to revive Louisiana's harsh anti-abortion law, not enforced since the 1973 Roe vs. Wade decision of the Supreme Court. The effort failed. Two people indicted in the gambling case along with Connick pleaded guilty last week. Aucoin's daughter, Darlene Peake, and Iris Ethridge, a bank employee who handled Aucoin's account at a suburban New Orleans bank, pleaded guilty to helping conduct an illegal gambling business. Federal prosecutors agreed to drop a more serious charge of racketeering in exchange for the women's cooperation. A charge of perjury against Ms. Ethridge also will be dropped, attorneys said.

DOC.HEAD: Ten Cities Given Designation as All-America Cities
DOC.TEXT: Ten cities from eight states _ from little Hamlet in North Carolina to a suburb of Los Angeles _ were designated All-America Cities by the National Civic League. The winners were announced Saturday night after the finalists gave presentations before a 12-member panel Friday and Saturday. The top 10: Abilene, Texas; Bakersfield, Calif.; Charlotte, N.C.; Coeur d'Alene, Idaho; Hamlet, N.C.; Harrisburg, Pa.; Sioux City, Iowa; Southgate, Calif., near Los Angeles; South St. Paul, Minn.; and Tampa, Fla. The 30 finalists were picked from a record 113 entries, said Chris Gates, vice president of the civic league. The All-America designation goes to cities that demonstrate an ability to solve local problems through community leadership, citizen participation, government, civic education and philanthropy. Each delegation gave a 10-minute presentation, spotlighting three projects its city has undertaken to show leadership and cooperation between private and government factions. ``We are very proud,'' said Mayor Abbie Covington of Hamlet, with a population of 6,640. The town, about 100 miles southwest of Raleigh, had never competed in the All-America Cities program. ``Thirty percent of our citizens are on a fixed income,'' said Ms. Covington. ``This just shows the support we can get from our folks.'' Among the three projects highlighted in Hamlet's presentation was the regeneration of the town's hospital. With a decline in patients and cuts in Medicare, the hospital was slowly dying, Ms. Covington said. But 4,000 of Hamlet's inhabitants signed a petition calling for the hospital to remain open and citizens formed a committee to show support for it. That led to a new lease for the hospital and caused a new 65-bed nursing home to locate in the southern town. The town also expanded its library with donated funds from citizens and re-established a railroad festival. The other cities produced presentations that spotlighted efforts to combat drug abuse and economic problems. The other 20 finalists were Brooklyn Center, Minn.; Beatrice, Neb.; Binghamton, N.Y.; Chattanooga, Tenn.; LaCrosse, Wis.; Birmingham and Gadsden, Ala.; Tempe, Ariz.; San Francisco; Montrose and Ouray, Colo.; Fort Lauderdale, Fla.; Oak Park, Ill.; Wichita, Kan.; Thibodaux, La.; Baltimore, Rockville and St. Mary's County, Md.; and Flint and Midland, Mich. The 41st annual competition, a program of the National Civic League, was sponsored by The Allstate Foundation.

DOC.HEAD: Parachutist Dies In Leap From Skyscraper
DOC.TEXT: Two skydivers leaped off the 54th floor of a partly built downtown skyscraper Sunday, and one man died when his parachute failed to open, police said. Robert Morris, 26, of Mount Joy in southeastern Pennsylvania was pronounced dead at the scene, police said. Rod Stoltzfus, 27, landed safely in a parking lot across the street just after dawn and left the scene, police said. Stoltzfus called his pastor and went with him to see Morris' family before contacting police, said Detective James Mooney. No charges were filed against Stoltzfus, who returned to his Manheim home, Mooney said. Lt. Giacomo Giovinetti said police would wait to decide whether to file charges until they talk to Stoltzfus, who was expected to return for questioning. ``We're going to find out just what the circumstances were,'' Giovinetti said. ``We're also going to talk to the district attorney.'' Giovinetti said charges could include risking a catastrophe, causing a disturbance and disorderly conduct. ``It's an irresponsible act, but it's not so cut and dried,'' he said. ``Someone obviously lost a loved one. I don't think we should be insenstive about this. They could have injured people on the ground, too.'' The pair jumped off the Mellon Bank building at 5:50 a.m., police said. Stoltzfus, who learned to parachute in the Army, has been skydiving for seven or eight years, said his brother, Brian, 17. Morris also was experienced, and the two were good friends, the brother said. On Aug. 26, a parachutist identified as a New York waiter jumped off the building's 47th floor. Three skydivers jumped off another skyscraper in 1986 while it was under construction; none was arrested.

DOC.HEAD: Janet Adkins Mourned by Family, Friends
DOC.TEXT: A woman who used a controversial machine to commit suicide rather than live through the mental destruction of Alzheimer's disease became a ``pioneer in the battle for death with dignity,'' her minister said Sunday. Friends and relatives gathered at the First Unitarian Church here for a memorial service for Janet Elaine Adkins, 54, who died last Monday in Michigan. An exceptional woman in life, ``Janet would become famous in death,'' said the Rev. Alan G. Deale. ``The public attention that her death has received is an indication of the level of interest in this phenomenon,'' he said. ``I have supported Janet's right to decide when she would end her life,'' Deale said, adding that the Unitarian Church supports ``death with dignity.'' The Unitarian Universalist Association in 1988 adopted a resolution that, acknowledging circumstances in which the inherent dignity of life may be compromised, supported the right to die in accordance with one's own choice. ``She desired control over her own decision in this matter,'' Deale said. ``To die a little later, or a little sooner, does not matter,'' he said. What matters is ``to live bravely, to love wisely, to see how beautiful the trees are, and even the sea _ to enjoy the world ...'' Mrs. Adkins had planned the joyful, hourlong ceremony before traveling to Michigan, where Dr. Jack Kevorkian hooked her up to the suicide machine he invented. She touched a button, releasing an anasthetic followed by a lethal injection. Seconds later, she was dead. ``Janet loved life, but she didn't fear death,'' said her friend, Judy Humiston. A spiritual person, Mrs. Adkins saw death as a passing into the next phase of her search for the ultimate truth, Humiston said. ``She did not fear death _ because we understand that life and death are necessary to reach heaven,'' Deale said. Humiston was one of three friends who spoke of their relationships with Mrs. Adkins, remembering her passion for life and her love of good conversation, challenge, philosophy, music, travel, teaching and tennis. ``Janet loved to win,'' Carol Rehmke recalled with a smile. ``Janet taught me to play chess and we played by mail. She won the first game and I won the second. And we never played the third game.'' Humiston, who knew Mrs. Adkins for 28 years, recalled how they had been young mothers together. They discussed their roles as wives and mothers _ and later, their roles as women as well, Humiston said, noting how Mrs. Adkins always challenged others to ask questions and to grow. ```I admired her ability to show life with such an optimistic and determined viewpoint,'' Humiston said. According to Mrs. Adkins' wishes, a quartet played a movement from String Quartet No. 2 in D by the 19th century Russian composer Alexander Borodin. Mona Warner and Ryc Williamson, on guitar and bass, respectively, performed the popular song, ``When I Need You.'' Deale urged everyone to sing joyfully the closing hymn _ Beethoven's Hymn to Joy _ as Mrs. Adkins had asked.

DOC.HEAD: Explosions Continue Aboard Stricken Supertanker; Sea Ablaze
With AM-Tanker Blast, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Thirty-six hours after an explosion ripped through a supertanker and set it ablaze, more blasts rocked the Mega Borg, sending burning debris into the sky like Roman candles and leaving oil pools burning on the Gulf of Mexico. The entire superstructure _ about the rear one-fifth of the ship _ was engulfed in flames. The fire's intensity had buckled the castle-like structure's steel walls and partially collapsed the ship's stack. The superstructure, blackened by fire Saturday, was a grayish white Sunday. Two thick columns of dark gray smoke, changing to deep black after a ball of flame would erupt from the blaze, rose more than 2,000 feet into the sky. The stern was no more than 5 feet above the water's surface, where pools of brown oil burned. The ship, apparently at anchor, listed slightly to port. At midday Sunday, two fireboats, occasionally joined by a third vessel, appeared to be focusing more on keeping the burning oil from spreading and keeping the cargo tanks cool than on extinguishing the flames, which licked from the front of the wheelhouse toward the cargo tanks. One fireboat, with ``Rescue One'' emblazoned on its side, shot two large streams of water to the starboard side, concentrating on the cargo decks. The other fireboat, the Carolyn Chouest, kept its two streams on the burning sea around the stern. A third boat helped when the fire on the water surface flared or when oil debris from an explosion flew beyond the immediate area. Water from hoses poured from the decks and over the gunwales. The tattered remains of the ship's flag, clearly visible on the stern Saturday, were lost in the smoke and flames Sunday. Four Coast Guard boats patrolled a perimeter several hundred yards around the ship Sunday, with several supply boats standing by. Trails of brown oil lingered hundreds of yards away from the ship, and slicks of light crude oil were visible as far as 16 miles away. Smoke from the fire could be seen 35 miles away.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Damages Offices of U.S. Company in Greece
DOC.TEXT: A blast from an anti-tank missile rocked a building housing offices of the U.S.-based Proctor & Gamble Co. late Sunday, causing damage but no injuries, police said. No one claimed immediate responsibility, but authorities said they suspected a leftist group known as November 17. There have been several bomb blasts in Athens over the last month. There have been no injuries from the attacks. Police initially said Sunday's blast was caused by a bomb that went off in the eight-story building, which also houses a Fiat motor showroom and local distributors of the Italian automaker. Later, police said they believed the blast was caused by an anti-tank missile slamming into the second floor offices that belong to the U.S. multinational. The Cincinnati-based company makes household cleaners, pharmaceuticals and other products. Its offices and the motor showroom on the ground floor were damaged in the blast, authorities said. In February, the November 17 group stole two World War II bazookas from the Athens War Museum. Experts said at the time that the weapons were serviceable. In the past, the group has declared its opposition to multinational corporations in Greece. It has been blamed for killing 14 people since 1975, but none of its members has been arrested. Last month, November 17 claimed to have set off several incendiary bombs in an Athens suburb. In the latest previous blast, a bomb went off June 1 and destroyed five cars. That attack went unclaimed.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Meets Mexican President on Trade Issues
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Retransmitting a0744 to fix writethru designation to 4th sted 3rd
DOC.TEXT: President Bush dined privately with Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari at the White House Sunday night and laid the groundwork for formal negotiations to lift trade barriers between the two countries. A White House spokesman said both presidents believe their countries would ``derive substantial and long-term benefits'' from a trade pact. The statement by White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater stopped short of announcing the start of formal negotiations to forge a free trade pact, but administration officials said they expect that announcement to come Monday. Both presidents declined to answer reporters' questions about free trade as they posed for photographers on the mansion's North Portico facing Pennsylvania Avenue. They went inside for a reception with top U.S. and Mexican economic officials, including, on the U.S. side, Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, Commerce Secretary Robert Mosbacher, trade representative Carla Hills, national security adviser Brent Scowcroft and Vice President Dan Quayle. Later, they dined alone in their second White House meeting in less than nine months. Salinas, who is in the United States on a private visit to address the Business Roundtable, will meet with Secretary of State James Baker III and members of Congress on Monday, and will resume ``consultations on the free trade issue'' in those meetings, Fitzwater said. Summing up the presidents' private meeting, Fitzwater said: ``Both leaders believe that the United States and Mexico would derive substantial and long-term benefits from a comprehensive bilateral trade agreement. They agreed that bilateral efforts to maximize trade and investment opportunities can and should complement the trade liberalization achieved in the Uruguay Round of the GATT (General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade).'' They also discussed the recent superpower summit, the fight against drug trafficking and other issues. Bush reiterated the U.S. desire for ``close cooperation with Mexican authorities'' in the drug fight, said Fitzwater. Administration officials said beforehand that the Bush-Salinas meeting would be followed by a formal announcement on Monday of negotiations to create a free trade pact. The officials asked not to be identified. Bush earlier Sunday declined to predict how long it might take to achieve a free trade agreement with Mexico. ``I want to talk to him first before I can say on that,'' Bush told reporters as he walked off the golf course at Andrews AFB in suburban Maryland earlier Sunday. But he called the meeting with Salinas ``very important.'' If successful, the trade negotiations could bring all of North America _ 335 million people _ into a single market free of tariffs and other barriers to trade. The United States and Canada entered a free trade agreement two years ago. Bush has close ties with Salinas, who paid a formal state visit to the White House last Oct. 3. This time, their get-together was an informal one, with the two presidents dining without aides present. Preparatory trade discussions are expected to begin shortly with an eye toward launching the formal negotiations before Bush and Salinas next meet in Monterrey in December. Two-way U.S.-Mexican trade now totals about $52 billion a year, but experts say it has the potential to go much higher. The reform-minded Salinas, 42, a Harvard-educated economist, is seeking to invigorate Mexico's economy. A free trade agreement could spur job creation south of the border and ease pressures that lead Mexicans to look for work in the United States illegally. But it would require dismantling tariffs and other barriers erected decades ago to protect Mexican industry from competition from its rich American neighbor. U.S-Mexican ties have been strained by the recent jailing in California of a Mexican physician, Humberto Alvarez Machain, who is accused of complicity in the murder of a U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agent in 1985. Bush said last month the United States played no role in abducting the doctor. But a DEA agent subsequently testified in Los Angeles that the agency had authorized a plan for Mexican police to kidnap the physician and deliver him across the border. Salinas and Bush both were elected in 1988. They met as presidents-elect in November that year in Houston, and then again last October as heads of state. On Monday, Bush will welcome East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere to the White House for talks on the new Germany and Europe. It will be the first meeting between a U.S. president and the head of East Germany, which until a few months ago was a hard-line communist state. Bush had dinner at the White House Friday night with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Bush and his family held a christening in the Rose Garden on Sunday for Walker Bush, the president's 12th grandchild.

DOC.HEAD: Rappers Arrested After Nightclub Performance
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with comments from sheriff, lawyer. Pick up 13th graf pvs, `Deputies had...
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MH1
DOC.TEXT: A rap group kept its promise to sing lyrics from an album ruled obscene and authorities kept their word, arresting two members of 2 Live Crew on Sunday after an adults-only concert. The early-morning arrests came four days after a federal judge declared obscene the Miami group's album ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be,'' and two days after a local record dealer was arrested for selling the popular recording. Broward County sheriff's deputies arrested 2 Live Crew leader Luther Campbell, 29, and singer Chris Wongwon, 26, shortly after the show at a Hollywood nightclub. ``We didn't want to create any commotion in there, so I told them to let them get out of there and arrest them away from the premises,'' said Sheriff Nick Navarro, who has led a campaign to ban sales of the group's records. Deputies pulled over the rappers' limousine a couple of blocks away from the club, said sheriff's spokesman Al Gordon. Only Campbell and Wongwon were taken because the group split up after the performance, heading in different directions in three vehicles, Gordon said. ``We didn't have enough deputies to cover them,'' he explained, adding that arrest warrants for members Mark Ross and David Hobbs would be issued Monday. Campbell and Wongwon were booked at the Broward County Jail on the misdemeanor charge of violating a prohibition against obscene performances. The charges were based on the group's performance of material from the album, which has sold more than 1.7 million copies. They were freed without bond. No court appearance was set. If convicted, they could face up to a year in jail and a $1,000 fine. Bruce Rogow, 2 Live Crew's lawyer, said the arrests amounted to police harassment. The rappers themselves had left for a concert in Phoenix and could not immediately be reached for comment. ``To have a dozen sheriff's officers spending all this time over some dirty lyrics seems to me to be obscene,'' Rogow said. Plainclothes deputies were inside the club early Sunday as the rap group led the crowd in chanting repeated insults aimed at Navarro, but Gordon said the arrests were not meant as retaliation. ``They announced on TV newscasts they were going to do the songs which the judge has ruled obscene,'' Gordon said. ``That's pretty much the same reason we arrested the shopkeeper.'' E-C Records owner Charles Freeman sold a record and a tape version of the album to an undercover deputy Friday in front of news photographers. He faces a first-degree misdemeanor charge and is free on $100 bond. Gordon said the arrests were in keeping with Navarro's ``contention that if you break the law in Broward County, you're going to jail.'' Deputies had been checking area record stores since the Wednesday ruling by U.S. District Judge Jose Gonzalez, Gordon said. The only copies of the double album they located were those confiscated in Friday's arrest, he said. About 15 police officers and 300 fans were on hand Saturday night as the rappers performed an early show for patrons of all ages at Hollywood's Club Futura. At that show the group performed what it calls the ``clean'' version of the album's songs, omitting the controversial lyrics. Many of the young concert-goers shouted the ``nasty'' lyrics themselves. About 400 people showed up for the later, adults-only ``nasty'' set early Sunday. In nearby Miami Beach on Friday night, 2 Live Crew performed the ``nasty'' lyrics at another adults-only nightclub show. That performance went off without incident or arrest, despite the fact that the club was in Dade County and therefore covered by the judge's ruling. The ruling declared the recording obscene in Broward, Dade and Palm Beach counties.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Prefer Home to Development Centers
DOC.TEXT: Contra rebels demobilizing after a 9-year-war are shunning development centers the government established as part of a peace agreement. Instead, they're going back home. ``Very few of us are going to go to the center because we prefer to see our people, whom we've gone years without seeing,'' said Filemon Cruz Lopez, an 18-year-old who said he joined the rebels eight years ago. ``We want to know what has happened in our homes,'' he said. Cruz was one of about 800 Contras, including six commanders, who turned in their weapons Saturday in a mass demobilization attended by President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro and Managua archbishop Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo. Despite the last-minute push, the rebels did not meet the Sunday deadline they had agreed to for completion of the demobilization. Officials of the U.N. Central American peacekeeping force and the International Verification and Support Commission, which are overseeing the demobilization, said Saturday it would take about 10 days before all the fighters are disarmed. Demobilization began May 7 under an agreement between the rebels and the government, but the process had been twice suspended. Waiting in line to turn in his AK-47 rifle to the U.N. troops, Cruz said he would return to Susucayan, in the northern province of Nueva Segovia, to work with his father, a farmer. Daniel Lozano, chief of operations for the verification commission said: ``Only 10 percent of the demobilized and disarmed rebels here have said they want to go to the development poles. The rest prefer that we take them home.'' Sonia Blandon, 19, said she turned in her weapons three days ago and was going to live in Las Colinas, two miles south of El Almendro. ``I have family that has lived here always. In addition, I have nothing to fear. The army has left also,'' she said. The government agreed to create more than 20 development centers in war zones and invested $47 million in U.S. aid in economic and social infrastructure. Manuel Garay, a 36-year-old rebel fighter and former farmer from Plan de Grama, Jinotega, said he expected few problems when he returned home. ``I haven't done anything bad to anyone from my place,'' he said. I don't owe anyone anything there. I believe I can return and go back to my work.''

DOC.HEAD: Bomb At Army Barracks Injures 17; Another Explosion in NIreland
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with explosion in Northern Ireland. Pickup 4th pvs, ``This should...'
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded in a military barracks rented for a birthday party, injuring 17 people, and police said Sunday the attack had ``all the hallmarks of the IRA.'' The explosion came just before midnight Saturday at the Honorable Artillery Company barracks, a turreted Victorian building near London's financial district. All of those injured were civilians. In Northern Ireland, an off-duty member of the Ulster Defense Regiment was seriously injured Sunday when a bomb exploded beneath his car, the Royal Ulster Constabulary said. No group claimed responsibility, but members of the locally raised British army regiment have been targets of frequent Irish Repubican Army attacks. There also was no claim of responsibility for the bombing in London, but police said it was similar to previous attacks by the IRA, which targets British soldiers and military installations. ``This should invoke abject contempt for the IRA throughout the whole of the United Kingdom and the Republic of Ireland,'' Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher told reporters on a flight back from a four-day visit to the Soviet Union. Scotland Yard said London blast was caused by a ``bomb of some sort.'' Detective Chief Superintendent Derek Willison, deputy head of the police force's anti-terrorist squad, said the device had been planted on the roof of the building in the previous 24 hours. The explosion ripped through the ceiling of the third-floor bar below, showering shattered glass and debris on the 30 guests attending the black-tie party. Twelve women and five men were treated for cuts and shock at nearby St. Bartholomew's Hospital and released. Hospital spokesman David Dalton said two women were kept overnight for observation of possible concussions. If the explosion was the work of the IRA, it would be the latest in a series of attacks that have been aimed at military targets but have killed or injured civilians. In the last two weeks, the IRA has killed six people, including two Australian lawyers who were shot to death in the Netherlands. The IRA later said it mistook them for British soldiers. It also has killed a British army recruit who was standing on a train platform, a British army major in West Germany and a retired reserve policeman and his wife in Belfast. The IRA wants to end British rule over Northern Ireland and unite the predominantly Protestant province with the mainly Roman Catholic Republic of Ireland. Police said the only connection between Saturday's party and the military was that the host's father was a member of the army reserves. It was a 21st birthday party for a Cambridge University law student, Mark Venn. Capt. David Venn said his son's party had been held in another part of the building and guests decided to have a nightcap at the bar before going home. ``I was standing by the bar getting some drinks when there was an explosion and a flash of light. I looked at the floor _ pieces of glass, bits of plaster,'' he said. The barracks' bar was not open to the general public, and on most Saturday nights it is full of reserve soldiers. ``There was no warning and there has been no claim, so it is hard to say, but it has all the hallmarks of the IRA,'' said Willison, the detective. The Honorable Artillery Company is part of Britain's volunteer reserve force, which can be called on in time of national emergency to reinforce the full-time army.

DOC.HEAD: Few U.S. Servicemen Take Offer To Return Dependents
DOC.TEXT: About 210 U.S. military personnel have asked to send their families home from the Philippines because of threats by Communist rebels to kill Americans, a military spokesman said Monday. Air Force spokesman Lt. Col. Ron Rand said as of Thursday, about 150 service members at Clark Air Base and 60 at Subic Bay naval base had taken advantage of the special offer to send dependents home at government expense before their tour of duty is over. He said that represented about 3 percent of those eligible at Clark and less than 2 percent at Subic. The offer was made earlier this month by Adm. Huntington Hardisty, commander of U.S. Forces in the Pacific. Rand said there has been no time limit set on the offer. Hardisty made the offer after Communist rebels killed two U.S. airmen on May 13 near Clark Air Base, 50 miles north of Manila. A Marine was killed near Subic naval base a week earlier, but police said the motive was robbery. The Marxist New People's Army has vowed to kill Americans until all U.S. troops leave the Philippines. The United States maintains about 40,000 troops, Defense Department civilians and military dependents at six installations here. U.S. personnel have been barred from leaving Clark Air Base because of the security threat. The New People's Army has been waging a 21-year-old insurgency to establish a Marxist state. Also Monday, two gunmen shot and killed the personnel chief of the Philippine military's Narcotics Command in an ambush near his home in suburban Paranaque, police said. Col. Rogelio Dumlao was driving to work when two gunmen with .45 caliber pistols opened fire, killing him instantly, police said. The police Capital Command said they were uncertain whether the assailants were Communist rebels or common criminals. The Nacotics Command not only tracks down drug offenders but has been used to hunt right-wing military dissidents responsible for the six coup attempts against President Corazon Aquino.

DOC.HEAD: Jet Fighter Crashes In Residential Area, Seven Killed
