DOC.TEXT: An Afghan air force jet crashed into a densely populated neighborhood in the Afghan capital Sunday, killing the pilot and six other people, state radio reported. Kabul Radio said the jet fighter crashed in Macrorayon, or ``small town,'' an area of apartments constructed by the Soviet Union. Several apartments were badly damaged and three vehicles caught fire, the radio said. The report gave no other details.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Opens Lower in Hong Kong
DOC.TEXT: Gold dropped 61 cents an ounce on Hong Kong markets Monday, opening at $356.07. It closed at $356.68 Saturday.

DOC.HEAD: New Governments Have Some Echos of Prewar Past
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with six grafs to UPDATE with Socialists ahead in Bulgaria; pickup graf 7, `In Poland...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Czechoslovakia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Eastern Europe's first free elections in decades have largely silenced the Communists, but not old strains of nationalism and other familiar songs of a more distant past. During the past last months, elections have been held in East Germany, Hungary, Romania, Czechoslovakia and Bulgaria, with much of the balloting coming on the heels of revolution. In Czechoslovakia, official results Sunday showed Civic Forum and its sister organization _ Public Against Violence _ won free elections on Friday and Saturday. The two paries spearheaded November's pro-democracy revolution. To many people in Prague, Civic Forum's founder, Vaclav Havel _ a prominent playwright and former dissident _ evokes memories of Tomas Garrigue Masaryk, who founded an independent Czechoslovakia in 1918. In Bulgaria, reform Communists who recast themselves as Socialist Party members took a commanding lead over the opposition in initial projections of Sunday's vote. It was Bulgaria's first free elections in 58 years. A Socialist victory in Bulgaria would be a return to the prewar past. Bulgaria's Communist Party was even older than its Soviet counterpart and was a strong political presence in Bulgaria for nearly 100 years. In Poland, as elsewhere, popular pressure forced the Communists to loosen their grip on power. After partially free elections last year, Poland's government fell to control by Solidarity, the broad-based movement born of labor unrest in 1980. After being suppressed along with Solidarity, the Roman Catholic Church _ as it was in the past _ is again a powerful political force. The picture is clouded in Romania. Although the Communist Party formally collapsed in the wake of the bloody December uprising that toppled dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, former Communist officials dominate the freely elected National Front government. But other aspects of the Romanian political scene are reminiscient of earlier times. Supporters of President Ion Iliescu paid him the kind of the homage normally accorded to past dictators. One slogan displayed by supporters was: ``Iliescu, When You Appear The Sun Shines.'' Hungary's first post-Communist government is that of Prime Minister Jozsef Antall's Democratic Forum, which won the March 25 elections on a platform of democracy. Antall placed heavy emphais on Hungarian pride in national traditions and customs shared by no other people. That was reminder of leaders past, including Miklos Horthy, who came to power in the 1930s and also played on nationalist concerns. The transition back to the future is perhaps most palpable for East Germans. After a popular movement forced out longtime Communist authorities, they are readying for union with West Germany, creating one Germany for the first time since World War II.

DOC.HEAD: New Module Docks with Space Station
DOC.TEXT: A high-technology module intended to help produce semi-conductors docked Sunday with the Soviet space station Mir, the Tass news agency said. The Kristall module was launched from the Baikonur site in Soviet Central Asia on May 31, but problems with its docking engines had prevented previous attempts to attach it to the Mir complex, manned by cosmonauts Anatoly Solovyov and Alexander Balandin. The launch also had been delayed a few times in recent days because of computer problems, Tass said. Approach and docking were controled by scientists on the ground and was completed Sunday afternoon. Kristall ``is intended for the production of high-quality semiconductors in conditions of weightlessness for the radio electronic industry,'' Tass said. It also contains equipment to conduct astrophysical, geophysical, biological and biotechnological experiments, Tass said. Semiconductors produced in zero gravity can be used in solar batteries aboard Mir, Tass said. The Kristall module reportedly contains enough material to produce several solar battery elements. Scientists want to compare the quality of the material produced in orbit with that manufactured on Earth, Tass said.

DOC.HEAD: New Explosions Hit Fire-Ravaged Supertanker
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead. INSERTS 1 graf after 7th graf, ``There certainly ...,' to UPDATE with stern stabilized; picks up 8th graf, `The latest ...' INSERTS 2 grafs after 11th graf, `Thousands of ...,' to UPDATE with airplane dropping dispersant, oil distributor to pay for cleanup; picks up 12th graf, `Seventeen of ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto HT4, LaserColor HT2
DOC.TEXT: A series of powerful explosions Sunday aboard a blazing supertanker that was carrying 38 million gallons of oil sent burning crude spilling into the water, officials said. ``This is a real big one,'' Coast Guard Chief Petty Officer Todd Nelson said. ``We've got burning crude oil rolling off the stern into the water.'' Authorities also said they were concerned that the ship's stern appeared to be listing. The five explosions hit nearly 1{ days after a blast and fire killed at least two crew members and forced evacuation of the 853-foot-long Norwegian tanker Mega Borg in the Gulf of Mexico. They were the latest in a series of smaller explosions that began Saturday afternoon. The ship's stern, where the fire was concentrated, has dropped by 58 feet since the first explosion Saturday, indicating either that the cargo had shifted or the Mega Borg was taking on water, Coast Guard Lt. Cmdr. Frank Whipple told a Sunday evening news conference. ``We're uncertain what that means,'' Whipple said earlier. ``It's not good,'' said Nelson. ``We don't know the possibility of it sinking. ``There certainly is a larger chance of the ship sinking than before the explosions,'' he said. ``We're still optimistic that the ship and cargo can be saved if there is an effective firefighting operation.'' By 9 p.m., the stern had stablized at 5 feet above the waterline, said Coast Guard Petty Officer Howard J. Holmes. The latest blasts, which began late in the morning and ended around 12:30 p.m., came shortly after members of a salvage team boarded the crippled ship to begin a full-scale assault on the blaze. They were off the ship before the blasts began, and there were no reports of injuries. Members of the Smit America Galveston Bay Salvage Team, hired by the ship's owners, were able to shut off some valves to the ship's tanks, Whipple told an earlier briefing. A spill about one mile long north of the vessel and one about 20 miles long to the south were visible Sunday evening. Prevailing currents and winds were expected to push the oil towards a 150- to 200-mile stretch of Texas coast between Freeport and Corpus Christi. Thousands of feet of containment booms were being brought in as a precaution in case a larger spill developed. The tanker, 57 miles southeast of Galveston, held 38 million gallons of light crude oil. A commercial C-130 airplane dropped dispersant over parts of the spill within a five-mile radius of the tanker late Sunday, Holmes said. Dispersants are used to make oil break up more quickly. ELF, a Houston-based oil distributor that was going to market the Mega Borg's cargo, is paying for the cleanup, Holmes said. Seventeen of the 41 crew members rescued were injured, none seriously, in Saturday's explosion. Two remained hospitalized Sunday in good condition. The Coast Guard's Atlantic Strike Team from Mobile, Ala., and other spill response groups brought a high-seas barrier boom and other supplies, including foam, to the ship. Four Coast Guard cutters were in place around the supertanker Sunday, Whipple said. Two Smit America ships were spraying water on the Mega Borg's deck to keep the ship as cool as possible, while two other salvage team ships were in position. Whipple said a full-fledged assault on the fire was scheduled for early Monday morning, when two other Smit America ships were expected to arrive at the scene. The full complement of salvage ships was expected to blanket the aft section with fire-extinguishing foam. The Mega Borg's owners also have contracted for an airplane to spread dispersants over about 7,000 gallons of oil spilled so far, Nelson said. Fireboats worked through Saturday night spraying water to cool the decks of the supertanker, said Petty Officer Richard Miled in Galveston. There were several minor explosions overnight, he said. Flames shot hundreds of feet high from the ship's air vents and thick, black smoke could be seen from 40 miles away after the engine room explosion at 1 a.m. Saturday. In addition to the two confirmed dead, two other crewmen remained missing Sunday and were presumed dead after a search for them was called off. Coast Guard Chief Petty Officer Rich Muller said the missing men from the crew of 41 were probably still aboard the ship. The blast occurred as part of its cargo was being transferred to a smaller tanker. The tanker, operated by Mosvolds Shipping of Farsund, Norway, was bound from Palanca, Angola. It was scheduled to travel to Aruba after its Galveston port of call. A telephone message left Sunday seeking comment from the Mega Borg's U.S. agent, Biehl and Co. of Galveston, was not immediately returned.

DOC.HEAD: Fujimori Wins in Peru, Vargas Llosa Concedes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 11th pvs, `Vargas Llosa's...' to CORRECT spelling of aide to Barnachea. Pickup 12th, ``It has...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos LIM1,3
DOC.TEXT: Alberto Fujimori, a political unknown four months ago, soundly defeated celebrated novelist Mario Vargas Llosa in a presidential runoff Sunday and promised to improve the economy of this bankrupt nation. Vargas Llosa conceded defeat. He wished Fujimori success in trying to turn the country around, fight drug trafficking and battle a decade-old guerrilla insurgency. Voting took place despite a wave of attacks in one Andean region by Maoist guerrillas who had vowed to sabotage the balloting. One voting station was bombed, and at least five people were killed and eight injured in separate attacks. Exit polls gave Fujimori, 51, an agricultural engineer and former university rector, a 13-to-19 point lead. The projections ``give us overwhelming support,'' Fujimori said at a news conference two hours after polls closed. He invited all political parties to participate in his government in areas where agreements could be reached. He said he recognized the ``titanic task'' of governing Peru and invited all political parties to participate in his government in areas where agreements could be reached. Fujimori said his government would stress economic development over military and police repression as the best way to fight both leftist subversion and cocaine trafficking. He did not indicate where the money would come from for economic development. The treasury is running a $100 million current deficit, and the nation has a $20 billion foreign debt. Before 1,000 supporters outside his campaign headquarters, Vargas Llosa conceded, wishing Fujimori ``success in the difficult responsibility the Peruvian people have placed on him.'' ``Respectful of democratic traditions, I accept the decision of the Peruvian people.'' Vargas Llosa's chief political aide, Alfredo Barnechea, called it a protest vote. ``It has not been a vote for a political program but a vote to stop Mario Vargas Llosa,'' Barnechea said after the televised projections were released. Fujimori, the son of Japanese immigrants, was vying with the center-right Vargas Llosa to replace populist Alan Garcia, whose five-year term ends July 28. Garcia, leader of the Aprista Party, is ineligible to serve a consecutive term. The election comes as Peru is weathering its worst economic crisis of the century. The impoverished Andean nation also is being bloodied by the savage, leftist insurgency that has claimed nearly 20,000 lives. The independent polling firm Apoyo gave Fujimori 51.1 percent to 37.8 percent for Vargas Llosa, with 11.1 percent blank and null votes. POP, another independent polling firm, showed Fujimori with 56 percent and Vargas Llosa 36.5 percent. POP put blank and null votes at 7.5 percent. Both firms based their projections on 100 percent of the vote nationwide. Both firms said their surveys had a 3 percent margin of error. The polls closed at 3 p.m. local time (4 p.m. EDT). Official returns were not expected for at least three weeks because of poor communication with mountain and jungle regions. Nearly 10 million Peruvians are registered to vote, and the law requires them to cast ballots. As the polls opened Sunday morning, armored helicopters crisscrossed Lima's sunny skies. Tanks and troop carriers patrolled the streets of the capital, home to a third of Peru's 22 million people. The Shining Path guerrillas, a Maoist group, bombed a polling station and killed at least one voter in Huancayo, a rebel stronghold in the Andes mountains, reporters there said. Guerrillas exploded at least nine other bombs in the city 120 miles east of Lima, police said. Voter turnout was very low in the city of 100,000. In a separate attack, rebels Sunday shot and killed three brothers, police said. A note found on one of the bodies said, ``This is how informers die.'' The body of a fourth man was found Sunday, police said. They said they had no further information. Rebel threats crippled transportation in three other mountain cities. Vargas Llosa, 54, ran on a free-market platform. He pledged harsh austerity measures to revive Peru's moribund economy and ease hyperinflation, running at 2,000 percent annually. Fujimori, is an independent like Vargas Llosa. He called for food subsidies and price controls and attacked Vargas Llosa's proposal for an economic ``shock'' program. Support for Vargas Llosa and Fujimori was deeply divided along class and geographical lines, polls indicated. Vargas Llosa was favored to win the April 8 first round, but Fujimori's popularity surged. Fujimori took a close second in the field of nine candidates and forced a runoff by denying Vargas Llosa a majority. Some pollsters said voters were inclined to cast a vote based on their opposition to one of the candidates. ``I'm voting for a Peruvian, not a Japanese,'' said Norma Olivas, a nurse, referring to Fujimori's Japanese roots. But Edith Vargas, who runs a curbside sandwich stand, cast her vote for Fujimori, saying: ``Vargas Llosa is in debt to the people with money, the capitalists.'' In some areas of the country, election officials suspended the requirement that voters dip their index fingers into indelible ink after casting ballots. In past elections, rebels have sometimes cut off the fingers of people who voted.

DOC.HEAD: English, Irish, German Fans Clash With Police in Italy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version has also been filed on the sports wire
DOC.TEXT: Riot police wielding batons clashed with groups of rowdy English-speaking soccer fans in a series of skirmishes Sunday night on the eve of a World Cup game between England and Ireland. Earlier Sunday, police in Milan in northern Italy clashed with a group of apparently drunken German soccer fans before West Germany's match against Yugoslavia. At least 23 people were reported injured and 39 fans detained in the clashes in Milan and in the city of Cagliari, on the island of Sardinia. In Cagliari, baton-wielding police charged into crowds of soccer fans gathered Sunday night on the main streets. The fans ran from the police, but at least three young men were taken from the scene in police cars. A police officer, who refused to give his name in keeping with Italian practice, said the authorities moved in to disperse the crowds of soccer fans after one of the fans threw a bottle and hit a woman in the head. At least 23 people, including eight police officers were injured and 36 taken into custody during the clashes in downtown Milan, police said. The skirmishes in Cagliari came late Sunday night after a day of calm on the eve of Monday's match between England and Ireland. Italian authorities had sent an additional 3,200 police to Sardinia because they feared that English fans, notorious for being rowdy, would turn violent. The three men who were picked up were not immediately identified by either name or nationality by the authorities. Fourteen English fans arrested Friday for street violence remained in custody and British authorities told their Italian counterparts that eight of the fans had previous police records, the Italian news agency ANSA reported. Some 8,000 English fans were expected in Sardinia for the match with Ireland. English club teams have been barred from European cup competitions since Liverpool and Juventus fans rioted during a 1985 match in Brussels. Thirty-nine people were killed.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarians Vote in First Free Elections in 58 Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS two grafs after 6th graf, `The Communist...' to ADD background on opposition party. Pickup pvs 7th graf, `The Association...'
DOC.TEXT: The ruling Socialist Party, formerly the Communist Party, held a commanding lead over the opposition in initial projections of Sunday's voting in Bulgaria's first free elections in 58 years. The winner in the balloting will set the tone for what is expected to be a coalition government. The ruling Socialist Party, formerly the Communist Party and once Moscow's most loyal follower, favors slow economic reforms. The main opposition alliance, the Union of Democratic Forces, wants a swift move to a Western-style market economy. Reform Communist leaders such as President Petar Mladenov and Defense Minister Dobri Dzhurov enjoy considerable popularity after ousting longtime dictator Todor Zhivkov in November. In Bulgaria, unlike other East bloc countries where street demonstrations brought down Communist regimes, reform Communists engineered the nation's drive to democracy. The Communist Party also has a long and successful tradition in Bulgaria. The party predates its Soviet counterpart and captured 20 percent of the vote in the nation's last free elections in 1932. Political observers said the Union of Democratic Forces lost potential supporters because of its poor leadership. In one instance, coalition leeder Zhelyu Zhelev refused on nationwide television to sign an agreement with the Socialists for a peaceful campaign. The pact had previously been initialed by other leaders of the Democratic Forces. The Association for Free and Fair Elections, a Bulgarian monitoring group, gave the Socialists 48.3 percent of the ballots against 34.9 percent for the Union of Democratic Forces and 8.3 percent for the Agrarian Party. The association has 10,00 people monitoring the elections. Its projection was based on results from 37.7 percent of the vote cast in the 200 races that will be decided by a proportional vote. The forecast was supported by the U.S. National Democratic Institute for International Affairs. Half of parliament's 400 seats are allocated on the basis of proportional representation while the other 200 go to candidates who receive more than 50 percent of the vote in direct balloting. The West German polling organization Infas also said the Socialists were leading the opposition coalition in the elections, state media reported. In areas heavily populated by the 1.5 million ethnic Turk minority, the Movement for Rights and Freedoms led by Ahmed Dogan apparently received about 80 percent of the vote, the state BTA news agency reported. BTA said final official results were expected to be released by late Monday. The main task of the unicameral parliament, the Grand National Assembly, will be to write a new constitution to usher in democratic and economic reforms. The Central Electoral Commission said late Sunday that at least 84 percent of Bulgaria's 6.4-million eligible voters cast ballots. Bulgaria, a country of nearly 9 million, last held multiparty elections in 1932. There were scattered reports of irregularities, including allegations of stolen ballot papers and last-minute campaigning, banned under electoral law. In some polling stations, voting was suspended because of a shortage of ballot papers, officials said. Electoral Commission President Zhivko Stalev said voting was only delayed to put new ballot papers in booths. ``Given the fact that these are the first free elections, and against the background of the elections as a whole, I would say that those minor infractions could not be regarded as something discrediting the elections as a whole,'' he said. In the race, 3,143 candidates from 38 parties vied for seats in the Grand National Assembly. Sofia residents began voting as soon as polls opened at 7 a.m. The voting stations officially closed at 6 p.m. but remained open in some areas so all those on line could cast ballots. Thousands of Bulgarian and foreign observers monitored the voting. A runoff is set for June 17 in constituencies where no candidate wins a majority. The assembly's goals will be to deal with growing inflation, a $10 billion foreign debt and acute shortages of basic consumer items including sugar and cheese. With Sunday's election, Bulgaria becomes the fifth Soviet bloc nation to hold multiparty balloting in the last four months after decades of one-party Communist rule.

DOC.HEAD: Panamanian President Marries Law Student
DOC.TEXT: President Guillero Endara married a 23-year-old law student Sunday, declaring he loves three things in this world: God, the Panamanian people and his bride. Among the guests of honor at the 54-year-old president's wedding were ambassadors of the United States, Latin American and European countries. Endara was installed during the U.S. invasion of Panama by U.S. forces that overthrew Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. About 250 people waited outside the Metropolitan Cathedral in a heavy rain to throw rice at the newlyweds when they emerged from the two-hour, Roman Catholic ceremony. As the president and his bride, Ana Mae Diaz, made their way from the church to the presidential palace next door, the umbrella-carrying crowd chanted ``Congratulations!'' in unison. Some shouted, ``Endara, friend, the people are on your side!'' The couple met at a university rally after Panama's 1989 elections. Endara won that election, but Noriega annulled the results. After the invasion, Noriega was brought back to the United States to face drug-trafficking charges. Endara was widowed one year ago. He has a daughter, Marcela de Yap, and a grandson Javier Yap, who was the ring bearer at the ceremony. After the traditional ceremony, Diaz threw her bridal bouquet of white flowers from the presidential palace's balcony to the crowd below. Endara declared that there are three things he loves, ``God, the Panamanian people and Ana Mae.'' Endara and Diaz kissed eight times during and after the ceremony, which was attended about 250 invited guests. Leaving the church, Diaz greeted wellwishers. ``I'm very happy,'' she said. ``I'm going to work for the country.'' Endara wore a black suit, white shirt and gray tie. The bride wore a traditional white wedding gown.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Socialists Win Special Japanese Election
DOC.TEXT: Japan's largest opposition party, the Socialists, won a special election Sunday for a seat in Parliament's upper house after campaigning for abolition of the sales tax. The voting was the first for a national office since the governing Liberal Democrats won an election for the more powerful lower house in February. In Sunday's vote, Socialist Shigeko Mieno defeated Norihiko Sumiyoshi, who belongs to Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu's party. With 95 percent of the vote counted, Ms. Mieno, 64, a former member of the Chikushino municipal assembly, had 829,913 votes. Sumiyoshi, a 43-year-old former member of the Fukuoka state assembly, had 717,577 votes, the election committee said. The seat for southern Japan's Fukuoka state had been held by Socialist Akira Ono, the upper house vice president, who died of illness on April 19. Ono was elected for a six-year term in July, when the Liberal Democrats lost their majority in the 252-seat upper house for the first time in their party's 34-year history. The governing party now has 110 seats, and the Socialists have 73. Ms. Mieno told reporters her victory resulted from her strong appeals for abolition of a 3 percent sales tax imposed in April 1989. The tax was seen as a major factor in the Liberal Democrats' upper house election loss in July. The Liberal Democrats have agreed to revise the tax.

DOC.HEAD: East German Prime Minister Addresses World Jewish Congress
DOC.TEXT: East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere said Sunday he understands Jewish concerns about a unified Germany, but said they are unfounded in this new era. ``Against the background of the past, I have full understanding for many Jewish citizens' anxieties for a united Germany,'' de Maiziere said in a speech to members of the World Jewish Congress. ``Nevertheless, I wish to emphasize: no one needs to have misgivings or even fears of a united Germany,'' he said. ``Germany today is totally different from Germany between 1933 and 1945.'' ``National socialism, as all dictatorships, could flourish only behind curtains of whatever kind. There can be no torture chamber in a common European home with all its doors and windows widely opened to all sides,'' de Maiziere said. The World Jewish Congress, which represents Jewish organizations in 70 countries, released de Maiziere's speech translated into English. Before the dinner, de Maiziere met privately with congress President Edgar Bronfman, and the two held a joint news conference. Bronfman said he was not overly concerned a united Germany might theaten the Jewish people. ``But being a Jew,'' he added, ``and having lived through the (Nazi) era, I'm never going to be totally relaxed about the situation.'' Through a translator, de Maiziere said Nazi-type atrocities ``are possible only under a totalitarian system and I suppose, as far as totalitarian regimes are concerned, we have thoroughly learned our lesson.'' De Maiziere was in New York to meet with representatives of the Conference on Jewish Material Claims, set up in 1951 to negotiate reparations to Israel for the deaths of 6 million Jews at Nazi hands. ``To us, attention to our Jewish fellow citizens is not an issue of social services or budgeting; it is a matter near to our heart,'' de Maiziere said in his speech. ``We shall, as soon as possible, provide the general conditions for specific negotiations on indemnification.'' The East German compensation could reach into the billions of dollars, but might be limited by the country's financial problems. East Germany ended nearly 45 years of communist rule with its first free elections in March, and is uniting with West Germany.Economic union is scheduled for completion by July, and West Germany is expected to assume many of its financially strapped neighbor's liabilities. Under a 1952 agreement, West Germany has paid more than $40 billion in reparations to Israel, Jewish groups and individual claimants. The Luxembourg Agreement called for West Germany to pay two-thirds of the total compensation. But East Germany's communist leaders, citing Nazi persecution of communists, refused to accept responsibility or pay the remaining third of the claims. After World War II, East Germany was dominated by the Soviet Union, which lost at least 20 million lives to the Nazis. One of the first acts of the new democratic East German parliament was to concede a share of the blame for the Nazis' deeds. ``All we can do is to try to learn our lesson from that period in German history and to keep alive memory of the victims and to fight passionately even the slightest manifestation of anti-Semitism, racism in general and xenophobia wherever they may crop up,'' said de Maiziere. On Monday, he was to head to Washington for the first White House meeting between an East German prime minister and a U.S. president.

DOC.HEAD: Oil From Spill Reaches Sandy Hook
With AM-Tanker Blast, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Tar balls from a major oil spill washed up on a New Jersey beach about 25 miles away Sunday, but the Coast Guard increased its estimate of how much oil will be recovered. A significant quantity of tar balls hit about a mile of Sandy Hook beach on Sunday, said Manny Strumpf, a spokesman for the Gateway National Recreation Area. The beach was closed to visitors during cleanup. Tar-like balls found Saturday on another beach nearby were being analyzed to determine if they came from the spill, said David Roach, city health officer of Long Branch, several miles south of Sandy Hook. Coast Guard Capt. Robert North said the cleanup will recover more than half the 260,000 gallons that leaked Thursday from the British tanker BT Nautilus into a heavily used shipping channel between Bayonne and the New York City borough of Staten Island. Hundreds of workers using five vacuum trucks, miles of containment booms and about 80 vessels have already recovered 104,000 gallons of the heavy industrial fuel from the shores and waters of the Kill Van Kull, the Coast Guard said. Usually less than 20 percent of a spill is recovered, but cool weather and cool water, which congealed the oil, plus a swift response, helped the cleanup, said Coast Guard Lt. Cmdr. Paul A. Milligan. The heavy No. 6 heating oil does not evaporate quickly, and workers were able to keep most of it boomed against the Bayonne shore, where vacuum trucks could suck it out of the water, he said. The busy Kill Van Kull fully re-opened to shipping Sunday morning. Oil was found washed up Friday and Saturday on several New York City beaches, including 800 pounds of oil globs on one Staten Island beach alone, but none was closed Sunday, Strumpf said. A Coast Guard board of inquiry was to begin hearings Monday on the Nautilus grounding and other incidents which, since Jan. 1, have dumped more than 1 million gallons of oil into the waters of New York harbor, four times the amount spilled last year. New Jersey and New York also were investigating the Nautilus grounding. Nautilus first mate Geoffrey Frederick Gregory of England was charged in New Jersey with operating a vessel under the influence of alcohol or drugs.

DOC.HEAD: Radicals Say Death Squads Formed to Kidnap U.S. Ambassador
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of militant students staged violent anti-government protests Sunday and radicals said ``death squads'' have been formed to kidnap the U.S. ambassador. About 9,000 students threw firebombs and stones at police in Seoul and six other cities Sunday to mark the anniversary of 1987 anti-government protests that brought widespread democratic reform. ``Drive out U.S. troops,'' screamed radicals hurling firebombs at police. ``Overthrow (President) Roh Tae-woo!'' At least six students were injured and about 200 arrested nationwide, the Yonhap news agency reported. In Seoul, radical leaders told The Associated Press that students in Kwangju have formed ``death squads'' to kidnap U.S. Ambassador Donald P. Gregg and block the reopening of a U.S. cultural center. At least 60 students in Kwangju have volunteered for the squads, said one radical student leader, speaking on condition of anonymity. Gregg, a former CIA station chief in Seoul and aide to then-Vice President Bush during the Iran-Contra affair, was scheduled to fly to the southern city of Kwangju on Monday to reopen the center at a new location. The center was closed after sustaining 29 attacks over 10 years by protesters hurling stones and firebombs. ``We will not allow the U.S. imperialists to reopen the cultural center,'' the student said. Three students wrapped in South Korean flags were arrested Sunday about 100 yards from the cultural center after scattering anti-American leaflets, Yonhap reported. In October, six students wielding iron pipes and homemade explosives attacked Gregg's residence in Seoul. Gregg and his wife were inside but escaped unharmed. Anti-American sentiment is particularly strong in Kwangju where citizens claim Washington condoned the suppression of a 1980 civil uprising against the martial law government. Some 200 civilians were killed and at least 1,700 injured in the uprising.

DOC.HEAD: American Sailors Rescued From Striken Yacht
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout with quotes from survivor; ADDS details; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Two Florida women whose yacht lost its mast in rough seas off Australia were rescued Sunday, an official said. A Taiwanese cargo vessel picked up the women, and an Australian army helicopter lifted them off the freighter's deck as the ship was tossed by 10-foot waves and buffeted by 30 mph winds, the official of Australia's Federal Sea Safety and Surveillance Center said. Jeannie Talley and Joy-Beth Smith of Crescent City, Fla., had radioed for help when the mast of their 36-foot yacht snapped on Thursday. Ms. Talley was not seriously injured during the ordeal, but she reported that her partner apparently broke her leg. The rescue occurred 400 miles off Australia's northern coast. The women had been sailing in their yacht Banshee to Vanuatu, a nation west of Fiji. After the rescue, the two Americans were taken by two Army Blackhawk helicopters to the Rockhampton base hospital, about 320 miles north of Brisbane. Interviewed afterward, Ms. Talley said she suffered from shock during the ordeal. ``It was the first time in my life I have ever been in shock, and I did not realize it until I was going to go out on deck. ...'' she said. ``I just got outside the hatchway, and all of a sudden I was paralyzed and weak.'' ``It was not until the third try before I could go out,'' said Ms. Talley, a sailor with 20 years' experience. She said the sea conditions were the worst she had ever seen. ``During the most intense part of the storm, we got rolled over 180 degrees,'' she said. Despite the scare, Ms. Talley said she and Ms. Smith plan to rerig the boat and sail again when weather permits.

DOC.HEAD: Ocean Liner Runs Aground in Dense Fog; Passengers Evacuated
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with ship freed, passengers arriving at dock, going to hotels; CORRECTS name to `Scot,' sted `Scott;' EDITS to tighten.
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of cruise ship passengers had to be ferried ashore Sunday after the ship ran aground in heavy fog and began taking on water, but no injuries were reported. The 617-foot Bermuda Star's hull was holed in two places when it slammed into submerged rocks about two miles from this village seaport on the southwestern tip of Cape Cod, Coast Guard officials said. None of the 680 passengers or 380 crew members was ever in danger, said Coast Guard Lt. Peter Keane. ``There was no panic on board,'' Keane said. Passengers, luggage and much of the crew were taken by commercial ferries across Buzzards Bay to New Bedford. The first crowded passenger ferry docked in a heavy downpour shortly before 7 p.m., where buses waited to whisk people to hotels in the Boston area. ``We were standing at the information desk (on the boat) when we heard this crunch,'' said passenger Wilfred Smith, 65, of Colorado, as he stepped onto the New Bedford pier. ``I said to my wife, `We hit something.''' Scot Graham, a Coast Guard marine safety officer in Providence, R.I., said the ship was three hours ahead of schedule and off course when it ran aground in the morning. ``I'm sure they didn't want to be where they were,'' Graham said. ``They should have been more south.'' Tugboats freed the ship from the rocks at 9:10 p.m., and it was anchored in Buzzards Bay, where divers patched up the hull holes, said Coast Guard Petty Officer 1st Class Dan Vineski. Earlier efforts to free the ship had been given up to await the high tide. Vineski said moving the ship did not appear to worsen a fuel spill. Graham said earlier that booms were used to contain an estimated 1,000 to 1,500 gallons of fuel that spilled from the ship's engine area, and workers used absorbent material to soak it up. Leakage was stabilized by the vessel holding steady on the rocks, said Coast Guard Petty Officer Greg Creedon. Flooding aboard the ship was under control by midday. The accident canceled the cruise, but was considered relatively minor. ``This is a kind of fender-bender for the marine world,'' Creedon said. Vineski said the ship's captain, whom he declined to identify, and other crew members took blood and alcohol tests routinely required after accidents. He said results were expected Monday. The accident occurred as the ship waited in the dense fog for permission from the Army Corps of Engineers to enter the Cape Cod Canal leading to Cape Cod Bay, Vineski said. It apparently strayed too close to shore and ran aground in water less than 30 feet deep, possibly on a rocky ledge. The Coast Guard got a distress call shortly after 8 a.m., Vineski said. Fog had cut visibility to about one quarter-mile when the accident occurred, officials said. The ship was en route from New York to Halifax, Nova Scotia. A stop had been planned for Sunday in Provincetown, on the north tip of Cape Cod. The ship, owned by the Bermuda Star Cruise Lines and sailing under a Panamanian flag, regularly cruises New England during the summer between the Philadelphia-New York area and the Canadian Maritimes. Woods Hole, near the island of Martha's Vineyard, is a major center for marine research.

DOC.HEAD: Ohio Flooding Shuts Down Section of Interstate
DOC.TEXT: High water shut down several miles of an interstate on Sunday after floodgates at Buckeye Lake were opened to reduce lake levels, authorities said. The body of a man who went rafting down a tributary of the rain-swollen Licking River was recovered from a logjam. About 3,000 people were temporarily evacuated from this central Ohio village Saturday because of fears an aging retaining wall would rupture and flood the area. ``It's looking a lot better today than yesterday,'' Mayor James Bartoe said Sunday. The lake was 12 inches higher than normal, but had dropped 6 inches since Saturday's heavy rains, said Police Chief Ronald Small. Floodgates were opened at the lake to relieve pressure on the wall, sending water into the south fork of the Licking River, making Interstate 70 to the north impassable. Recreational boating was banned on Buckeye Lake until further notice, Small said. Dispatchers for the State Highway Patrol said I-70 was closed periodically Saturday night and Sunday. The highway was reopened late Sunday afternoon, said dispatcher Julie Miller. The body of Brian Hinger of Newark was recovered in a logjam in the north fork of the Licking River north of Buckeye Lake near St. Louisville, Newton Township Fire Chief Jim Glover said. Hinger, 21, and a friend had gone rafting Saturday night on an inner tube when they were entangled in a logjam, Glover said. His friend, Ardell Hollobaugh, 22, of Newark, was rescued. Both men were scuba divers and experience lifeguards, Glover said. Robert Frey, an inspector with the Federal Emergency Management Agency, examined flood damage Sunday and said he would recommend that Licking County be declared a federal disaster area. Gov. Richard Celeste on Saturday declared Licking County in a state of emergency, and asked President Bush to declare it a disaster area.

DOC.HEAD: Caples Who Wrote ``They Laughed When...'' Ad Dead at 90
DOC.TEXT: John Caples, who as a young copywriter wrote one of advertising's most famous lines _ ``They Laughed When I Sat Down at the Piano...'' _ died Sunday. He was 90 years old. Caples, who lived in Manhattan, died at Lenox Hill Hospital. Caples wrote the famous headline in 1926 for the U.S. School of Music. The entire headline read: ``They Laughed When I Sat Down At The Piano...But When I Started To Play!'' The ad was an instant success and spawned dozens of imitations over the years that used ``They Laughed when...'' as the introduction. Caples, who went on to become an expert in direct-response advertising, had worked one year at Ruthrauff & Ryan when he wrote the famous ad. A year after the music school ad, Caples switched to Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn, where he spent the rest of his career. He went on to become a vice president in 1941 and retired as creative director in 1982. He wrote several books on advertising and was credited with developing copy testing and research for advertising campaigns. The native New Yorker graduated from the Naval Academy in Annapolis in 1924. He was called back into the Navy during World War II, and rose to the rank of commander. Caples is survived by his wife, Dorothy.

DOC.HEAD: Archbishop Appeals for End to Impunity
DOC.TEXT: The Archbishop of San Salvador on Sunday accused police of torture and appealed for prosecution of those who abuse human rights. ``There is a great clamor against the impunity that _ by the design, tolerance and perhaps maliciousness of military and judicial authorities _ reigns in the country,'' Archbishop Arturo Rivera Damas said in his Sunday homily at the Sacred Heart basilica. Rivera Damas, the country's highest Roman Catholic authority, also condemned the destruction of evidence in the case of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter who were murdered by soldiers last November. The Supreme Court said last week that a lieutenant, one of nine soldiers charged with the murders, burned pertinent military log books on orders from his superior. ``This is a manifest abuse of power because arms are not in the hands of the military to impede the functioning of justice, but rather to assure the application of justice,'' the archbishop said in comments to journalists following the Mass. Rivera Damas denounced what he said was the torture last week of Carlos Gonzalez Perez by members of the National Guard, one of three police forces. Gonzalez, a Spaniard, was arrested June 4 and held at National Guard headquarters until he was released into the custody of the Spanish Embassy on Thursday. No charges were filed against Gonzalez, who reportedly was a social worker employed by the San Salvador archdiocese. Rivera Damas used the word ``torture'' in describing the treatment of Gonzalez, but gave no further details. Spanish diplomatic sources said Gonzalez ``was in bad physical and psychological shape'' when handed over to embassy personnel. Gonzalez was flown to Costa Rica, where he was hospitalized. Rivera Damas also condemned murders carried out by right-wing and leftists hit squads. At least 71,000 people have died in the decade long civil war.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: This package does not contain the following items from the News Digest: WASHINGTON _ Animal Rights; MIAMI BEACH, Fla. _ 2 Live Crew; GALVESTON, Texas _ Tanker Blast. ___
DOC.TEXT: Gang violence in Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's home province has taken 400 lives in a month, and many Pakistanis fear it endangers their country's brief experiment with democracy. Ms. Bhutto, who campaigned for a decade to free Pakistan from military rule, has been forced to call out the army in Sindh, her native province in southern Pakistan. No one knows who is killing whom. Private armies, drug gangs and ethnic militias operate at will. Kidnappings, indiscriminate shootings and armed robbery are commonplace. Police have arrested more than 3,300 people in a weeklong sweep of Sindh province, the heart of the country's financial and industrial base.

The two political groups that broke the grip of Communist rule on Czechoslovakia won the first free election in 44 years and on Sunday began considering possible partners in a new coalition government. Official results showed that Civic Forum and Public Against Violence _ the Czech and Slovak sister organizations that led November's pro-democracy revolution _ had captured the most seats in the new federal Parliament. The two movements won 169 of the 300 seats in the bicameral Parliament, but they fell short of the three-fifths majority needed to make key constitutional and economic reforms necessary to fulfill the goals of the revolution. The Civic Forum, founded by President Vaclav Havel, had said before the election on Friday and Saturday that it would seek a coalition government.

Pizza makers are slinging the high-tech pie of the 1990s across America _ nitrogen-frozen, credit-card ordered via satellite and with pineapple and bacon on top. The state-of-the-art pizza methods _ all already in use _ were touted over the weekend at the National Pizza and Fast Food Show in Manhattan, where the American version of the Italian dish was introduced in 1895. In Albuquerque, N.M., drive-up dining is a pizza order made through a car window into a TV monitor at Nunzio's and, 60 seconds later, a pie down a pneumaode to a satellite. And, from Murray Hill, N.J., Airco uses liquid nitrogen to chill out the forgetful pizza lover who otherwise might reach into the freezer past a pizza's prime.

A series of powerful explosions aboard the burning supertanker Mega Borg on Sunday sent crude oil spilling into the water and bursting into flames, authorities said. The five explosions, which ended at 12:30 p.m., came shortly after members of a salvage team boarded the crippled ship to launch the first step of a full-scale assault on the fire. They were off the ship before the explosions began. ``This is a real big one,'' Coast Guard Chief Todd Nelson said. ``We've got burning crude oil rolling off the stern into the water.'' Authorities also said they were concerned that the ship's stern appeared to be listing. The latest series of five explosions struck nearly 1{ days after an explosion and fire killed at least two crew members and forced evacuation of the 853-foot-long Norwegian oil tanker in the Gulf of Mexico. The blasts were part of a series of smaller explosions that began Saturday afternoon.

A rap group kept its promise to sing lyrics from an album ruled obscene and authorities kept their word, arresting two members of 2 Live Crew on Sunday after an adults-only concert. The early-morning arrests came four days after a federal judge declared obscene the Miami group's album ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be,'' and two days after a local record dealer was arrested for selling the popular recording. Broward County sheriff's deputies arrested 2 Live Crew leader Luther Campbell, 29, and singer Chris Wongwon, 26, shortly after the show at a Hollywood nightclub. ``The deputies let them get a couple of blocks away from the club and then they pulled the limousine over,'' said sheriff's spokesman Al Gordon.

Thousands of animal rights activists rallied in the nation's capital Sunday seeking to promote the humane treatment of animals in the wild, on farms and in research laboratories. Many marchers advocated an end to the use of animals in medical research, a goal that top health officials say is misguided and could end advances in medical research. U.S. Capitol Police estimated 24,000 people attended a rally on the steps of the Capitol following the one-mile march down Pennsylvania Avenue under sunny skies. But organizers claimed more than 50,000 people from around the country showed up. Marchers chanted ``Animal Rights _ Now.''Many carried banners and placards with pictures and slogans saying things such as ``Animals Are Not for Wearing,'' ``Fur Is Dead,'' and ``Animals Have Rights, Too.'' Some even brought their dogs.

DOC.HEAD: Sematech Employees Bid Emotional Farewell to Noyce
DOC.TEXT: Employees of Sematech paid a final farewell to the late Robert Noyce, the ``Father of Silicon Valley'' who led the government-industry consortium in a bid to recapture chip-making leadership for the United States. Nearly all 600 of Sematech's Austin employees turned out for Saturday's ceremony, which company officials insisted on keeping upbeat rather than somber. ``I think it's entirely appropriate for us to laugh this morning, for us to applaud, for us to cry,'' said Charles Sporck, Sematech chairman. Noyce revolutionized electronics by co-inventing the semiconductor and later lobbied for the establishment of Sematech, whose members include 14 leading U.S. semiconductor and computer companies. Noyce, 62, died June 3 after suffering a heart attack at his Austin home. About 800 people, including other chip industry officials, Noyce family members, U.S. Rep. J.J. `Jake' Pickle, and Japanese journalists paid their respects to Noyce. Sematech provided the crowd with breakfast rolls, punch and soft drinks. Many executives also wore Noyce T-shirts, which proclaimed the late executive a ``teen idol.'' The ceremony also featured videos of the Silicon Valley pioneer and testimonials from friends and family. ``His inventions literally changed life on this planet,'' said Sematech spokesman Joe Stroop. Other employees were impressed with Noyce's ability to mingle with them on the job. ``He ate in the cafeteria with us,'' said Harriett Sickels, a manufacturing specialist. ``In most companies you don't even meet the CEO,'' added Ed Sailor, an equipment maintenance specialist. ``We are a very close group of people.'' Kenji Fukasawa, Houston bureau chief of the Japan Economic Journal, said Noyce enjoyed tremendous popularity in Japan. The Japanese public has followed memorial events after his death very closely as well as speculation about Sematech's future, he said. Noyce was slated to step down as Sematech chief executive before his death. In April, a search began to replace Noyce, who had agreed informally to be Sematech's chairman once a new chief executive was chosen, Stroop said. After becoming chief executive in 1988, Noyce worked to gain support for the research consortium both within the microelectronics industry and in the federal government. Noyce and Jack S. Kilby, a scientist at Texas Instruments Inc., invented the integrated circuit in separate research efforts in the late 1950s. At the time, Noyce was working for Fairchild Semiconductor Corp. Their invention prompted rapid gains in computer technology by putting the power of multiple transistors on a single chip. It helped make possible personal computers, pocket calculators and microwave ovens. Noyce co-founded Intel Corp., the nation's third-largest semiconductor producer, in 1968.

DOC.HEAD: $50 Million Payment Brings Pathe's Deposits to $200 Million in MGM-UA Bid
DOC.TEXT: Pathe Communications Corp. made the final installment on a $200 million cash deposit toward its $1.2 billion purchase of MGM-UA Communications Co. Pathe made its fourth and final $50 million deposit Friday. Under terms of the purchase agreement, the $200 million is non-refundable. MGM-UA also has been guaranteed a return of $75 million from distributing three upcoming Pathe films as part of the deal. The $20-a-share tender offer had been scheduled to close Thursday, but Pathe exercised an option to extend it until next Friday while trying to complete financing arrangements. Pathe can extend it until June 23 under its agreement with Kirk Kerkorian, the billionaire who controls MGM-UA. Many analysts and entertainment executives questioned whether Pathe chief Giancarlo Parretti, an Italian financier who had tried and failed to buy Hollywood companies in the past, could manage to finance the MGM-UA deal. Time Warner Inc. has agreed to lend Pathe half the $1.2 billion, with the valuable United Artists movie library as security. Parretti said Thursday he is trying to renegotiate parts of that agreement to get easier terms. Pathe says the balance of the money will be provided by Comfinance S.A., Paretti's Luxembourg holding company, and other European companies also controlled by Paretti and his associates.

DOC.HEAD: Contractors Say Secret Navy Plane Will Be Delayed
DOC.TEXT: The team of defense contractors building the secret A-12 Navy attack plane says the plane will not be flying by early next year as originally planned. The two St. Louis-base companies, General Dynamics Corp. and McDonnell Douglas Corp., said in separate statements Friday that ``there will be a delay in the first flight of the aircraft beyond early 1991 to later the same year.'' The team said the program itself is sound, however. ``The schedule delays permit completing the strong technical basis of the program before conclusion of final tooling and production of the development test aircraft,'' General Dynamics said in a terse statement. ``The A-12 industry team is confident that the desired operational capabilities of the A-12 will be met,'' the company said. ``Further detail is unavailable as the program is classified, but General Dynamics emphasizes that the A-12 will be superb high technology aircraft for the Navy.'' Both companies said they are working on revised schedules and new estimates of their costs to complete the program. That review, said both industry giants, could result in substantial adverse impacts on their second quarter earnings.

DOC.HEAD: Carrier Will Delay Delivery of New Airplanes, Chairman Says
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of USAir Group Inc. said the nation's seventh-largest airline will postpone delivery of a dozen new aircraft for more than three years because of sluggish business. Chairman Edwin I. Colodny said Friday the airline would delay delivery of the Boeing Co. planes from 1991-92 to 1995. ``The economy is soft. Travel is down,'' Colodny told reporters after a luncheon meeting of the Greater Pittsburgh Chamber of Commerce. ``I don't think we should fool ourselves and say everything is rosy. It's not.'' A Boeing spokesman expressed surprise at the news. ``I have never heard of a firm order being delayed like that,'' said Jack Gamble of Boeing Commercial Airplane Group. USAir spokesman John Bronson on Saturday confirmed Colodny's statement and said the planes involved were all Boeing 737s. Bronson said the proposal to defer delivery until 1995 was included in Colodny's recent letter to all USAir employees. In exchange for delaying the deliveries, USAir agreed to buy 24 more planes from the manufacturer and purchase options on 56 more aircraft after 1995, Colodny said. USAir has one of the airline industry's younger fleets and will delay retiring some planes, Colodny said. USAir lost $76 million in 1989 after 13 consecutive profitable years. The airline lost $38 million in 1990's first quarter. In last year's annual report, the company said it had commitments to buy five Boeing 767s before 1992 and 55 Boeing 737s before 1993. Projected spending on new planes was $882 million this year, $767 million in 1991 and $264 million in 1992, the report said.

DOC.HEAD: Airline, Flight Attendents End Hiring Dispute
DOC.TEXT: American Airlines and its flight attendants have agreed to settle lawsuits stemming from the carrier's decision to place foreign attendants on its Latin American routes, according to a top union official. Under a compromise, the company will hire about 200 foreign nationals as flight attendants on Latin American routes acquired from Eastern Airlines. In turn, American has agreed to use more domestic attendants on flights departing from its Miami hub to destinations in Central and South American, according to Cheryle Leon, president of the Association of Professional Flight Attendants. ``We feel it is a good agreement,'' Ms. Leon said. A spokeswoman for American reached Sunday said she couldn't confirm details of the agreement. American had sued the union, seeking a court ruling to allow it to hire foreign nationals. The union filed its own lawsuit, seeking to block American's plan to hire the foreign attendants. The company also has agreed to reduce foreign language requirements by asking that some, but not all, flight attendants be required to speak the language of a destination country, Ms. Leon said. The dispute between American and the 17,000-member union began last year when the airline agreed to buy routes and other assets for $310 million from Eastern. American plans to begin flights into Latin American in July.

DOC.HEAD: Japanese Makers Reportedly Dominate Powers Survey
DOC.TEXT: Toyota's year-old Lexus division ranked first in a survey of car-owners' attitudes about the quality of their 1990 cars, a newspaper reported. Japanese makers dominated the top of the ranking, and General Motors Corp.'s Buick was the only domestic division in the top five in the J.D. Powers & Associates Initial Quality Study, the Detroit Free Press reported Saturday. The annual survey focuses on car buyers' evaluations of 1990 models after three months of ownership. Lexus took the top rank with reports of only 82 problems per 100 vehicles. Mercedes was second with 84, followed by Toyota with 89; Infiniti with 99 and Buick with 113. The rest of the top 10 were Honda, 114; Nissan, 123; Acura, 126; BMW, 130, and Mazda, 130. Some automakers use the widely recognized Powers' survey to tout their performance in ads. The Buick LeSabre was the only domestic model ranked among the 10 most trouble-free cars of the 1990 model year. Last year it had been joined in the top 10 by the Ford Crown Victoria and the Buick Riviera. A spokesman at J.D. Powers in Agoura Hills, Calif., declined to confirm the report and said results of the survey won't be released until July.
